editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Preface to the Reader.
div.p: THe differences and di≈øagreements are ≈øuch, which in the≈øe fewe yeares la≈øt pa≈øt haue bred, and daily grow to more and more perfection in that kind, to ≈øo great a di≈øgu≈øt of all ≈øincere Catholickes, not onely here in England but al≈øo in the principall, if not in all the parts of Chri≈øtendome, whither the worthie fame of their memorable acts for the restoring of their natiue Country vnto the Catholicke faith hath come, that it is high time to giue them ≈øome ta≈øte of the≈øe matters, who are ≈øo di≈øgu≈øted, by laying before them the true cau≈øe, and grounds of this lamentable di≈ø≈øention, and to di≈øcouer how colourably the common enemie of God, and his Church, hath proceeded to the di≈øturbance fir≈øt of Gods Prie≈øts, then to the mutual di≈ølike of Catholickes among them≈øelues, and of ≈øuch Priests as again≈øt whom by wrong informations they are violently led, and let not to v≈øe both tongue and penne in mo≈øt vngratefull manner.

Some, being asked by others what might be the cau≈øe of ≈øo great a ≈øtrife among the Prie≈øtes, haue ≈øimply an≈øwered that the cau≈øe is, for that the Prie≈øts being but ≈øecular men will not humble them≈øelues, or be directed or gouerned by the Ie≈øuites, who are religious; but what truth ≈øoeuer is in this cau≈øe, of all other it mu≈øt not be giuen, for ≈øuch a ≈øubiection, euen in the eares of tho≈øe who de≈øire it, ≈øoundeth ≈øo ab≈øurdly, that they endeuour rather to haue it, then to heare of it, and both M. Blackwell in his Letters to the Cardi. Caietan dated the 10. of Ianuary 1596. and F. Par≈øons in his Letters again≈øt M. Doctor Bi≈øh: and M. Ch: dated the 9. of October 1599. labour to put this conceit out of mens minds, how euidently ≈øoeuer the practi≈øe in Wisbitch to make Fa. We≈øton the Ie≈øuite ≈øuperiour ouer the ≈øecular Priests (who then were in
durance for the Catholicke faith: pur≈øued both by the knowne, and couert Ie≈øuites, and all other their fauourites doth proue it, as al≈øo a Libell giuen abroad by the Authour thereof him≈øelfe, to admoni≈øh others to beware of ≈øuch Prie≈øts (and by no meanes to haue any dealing with them in ≈øpirituall matters, euen to the di≈øturbing of them out of their places of re≈øidence) as vnfit guides for ≈øoules, who had not a dependance of the Ie≈øuites. And not long ≈øince another of their fauourites letted not to ≈øay, that tho≈øe Prie≈øts who are not vnder the Ie≈øuites gouernment are no better then the Mini≈øters; Many more proofes may be made hereof out of the ≈øpeeches of many other their fauourites, who giue coun≈øell to all that are afflicted in the≈øe turmoyles to ≈øubmit them≈øelues to the Ie≈øuites.

Other ≈øome, (who perceiue well, that, if this ≈øhould be maintained to be the true cau≈øe of ≈øo ≈øcandalous a ≈øchi≈øme in Gods church, it would redound to the eternall di≈øgrace, & infamie of ≈øuch, as, by whom they hauing conceiued ≈øome fooli≈øh hope of preferment, they had rather that they ≈øhould indeed beare the ≈øway, & haue the gouernment of the Cleargie (although it were vnderhand) then be ≈øaid either to ≈øeeke it, or to haue it) giue out that the cau≈øe of this diui≈øion among the Prie≈øts is, for that ≈øome Priests mooued either with ambitioÃÑ, or de≈øire of contradiction, will not ≈øubiect them≈øelues vnto their lawfull ≈øuperiour appointed by his holine≈ø≈øe, and confirmed in authoritie ouer them by his Breue ≈øent into England for that purpo≈øe: and the≈øe haue from time to time both written, and maintained in mo≈øt iniurious manner (to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the more perfectly ≈øuch as are too readie to thinke no calumniation too greeuous euen again≈øt tho≈øe who haue be≈øt de≈øerued of them) that the≈øe Priests are ≈øchi≈ømatickes, ≈øeditious, rebellious, &c. euen to the diuiding for this cau≈øe of parents and their children, men and their wiues, brothers and ≈øi≈øters, and whole hou≈øholds, while the one retaining that reuerend respect of their long knowne, and tried ghostly fathers, for learning, wi≈øedome, and vertue, is a≈ø≈øailed by the other with the≈øe most wicked ≈øuggestions, and fal≈øe calumniations, and forced either to liue a di≈øcontented life, or to break friend≈øhip; and (again≈øt their owne con≈øciences) make ≈øemblance at the lea≈øt that they conceiue hardly of ≈øuch as they very well per≈øwade them≈øelues wil not
commit ≈øo great offence again≈øt God, and his Church, in who≈øe defence they haue ≈øpent many yeares, and remaine ≈øtill re≈øolute to ≈øhead their deare≈øt bloud.

That therefore no errour be hereafter in any man, who will not too much affect ignorance in ≈øuch things as concerne not onely his particular good but the Common cau≈øe of God, & his Church (which whiles the Cleargie liueth at ≈øome variance in an euill affected Countrey, cannot doubtle≈ø≈øe but be very greatly preiudiced therby) it is thought expedient, yea nece≈ø≈øarie, that the cau≈øe of this di≈ø≈øentioÃÑ be with truth, and ≈øinceritie declared, & made knowne to the world, that our actions and the rea≈øons thereof being weighed with equall ballances, truth may take place, the offerers of the wrong may be di≈øcouered, the vniu≈øtly afflicted may be relieued, and that ea≈øe (at the lea≈øt by the≈øe meanes) may be procured, which would not come of ≈øo long ≈øufferance.

The ≈øtrife, and di≈ø≈øention at this day too great, and ≈øcandalous in England, is maintained by the Arch-prie≈øt, the Ie≈øuites, & their adherents, again≈øt tho≈øe Prie≈øts who did forbeare to ≈øubiect them≈øelues vnto the Arch-prie≈øt con≈øtituted in authoritie ouer all the Seminary Prie≈øts in England and Scotland by a Cardinall, who was Protector of the Engli≈øh Colledge at Rome, and afterwards honoured with the title of Protector of England, for the which forbearing to ≈øubiect them≈øelues at the fir≈øt making knowne of this authoritie, the Prie≈øts were accu≈øed of ≈øchi≈øme, ≈øedition, faction, rebellion, &c. All which calumniations were forgiuen by the Prie≈øts ≈øo grieuou≈øly iniuried, and a peace made to the great comfort of all Catholiques, when his holine≈ø≈øe Breue was pre≈øented vnto them, but this peace was ≈øoone after broken by the meanes of the Ie≈øuites, who reuiued the ≈øame calumniations again≈øt the Prie≈øts, and by the Arch-prie≈øt, who did not onely auerre the a≈ø≈øertions of the Ie≈øuites, but publi≈øhed al≈øo that he had receiued a re≈øolution from the mother Citie (to v≈øe his tearmes) which avowed that the refu≈øers of the authoritie (noting by this phra≈øe the Prie≈øts who did forbeare for a time vpon cau≈øes ≈øeeming iu≈øt to them to accept thereof) were Schi≈ømatickes. So that the cau≈øe of this diui≈øion now in England, is not for any re≈øistance in the Prie≈øts again≈øt the
≈øuperioritie, as many forward and euill taught people per≈øwade them≈øelues, & cry out again≈øt the prie≈øts, that they are di≈øobedient. But the cau≈øe of this diui≈øion is, for that the Prie≈øts will not acknowledge that in the time of their forbearance to ≈øub≈øcribe to the authoritie (which was no longer then vntill they ≈øawe the Breue) they were factious, ≈øeditious, rebellious, Schi≈ømatickes, enormiou≈øly di≈øobedient, in continuall mortall ≈øinne, practi≈øing their function in irregularitie, and pretending to ab≈øolue from ≈øinne without faculties, or iuri≈ødiction meete therevnto, wor≈øe then South-≈øayers and Idolaters, &c. If therefore ≈øufficient rea≈øons may be giuen why the Prie≈øts did forbeare to ≈øubiect them≈øelues before they ≈øawe any Letters from his holine≈ø≈øe concerning this authoritie, it will both appeare how greatly they haue bene iniuried both by the Archprie≈øt, Ie≈øuites, and their euill nurtured children, and how nece≈ø≈øarie this cour≈øe of publi≈øhing in this ≈øort, is for the purging of the other Prie≈øts from tho≈øe ≈ølaunderous ≈øpeeches; and here by the way do we aske of tho≈øe pious Catholiques, (for ≈øo they mu≈øt be tearmed how≈øoeuer they de≈øerue it,) when they charge, and per≈øwade them≈øelues that they choake the Prie≈øts with di≈øobedience, what it is, that they meane by this di≈øobedience, if they meane therby that the Prie≈øts do not acknowledge M. Black. for their Arch-prie≈øt and ≈øuperiour, they may if it ≈øo plea≈øe them correct this their vnderstanding, and from henceforth either beleeue that euery man dooth acknowledge him, or el≈øe name who doth not, and let him in particular be called in question for it: for this generall prattle that they are di≈øobedient is ≈øo vn≈øauourie a ≈øhift, vnle≈ø≈øe they could di≈øcend to particulars, that a man with litle honestie would quickly perceiue how it doth taint his breath:

If by di≈øobedience in the Prie≈øts they do meane the not yeelding or conforming their vnder≈øtanding to the Arch-prie≈øt his vnder≈øtanding, they exact this obedience to the Arch-prie≈øt either becau≈øe that he is learned, or becau≈øe that he is a ≈øuperiour, but neither of the≈øe respects conuince any ≈øuch matter, as that the refu≈øing to be ≈øo conformable ≈øhould bring with it ≈øchi≈øme, ≈øedition, faction, rebellion, &c. Not the fir≈øt, which is in regard of his learning. For although that many in England for modestie ≈øake onely make
no compari≈øons with him for his learning, yet without offence we may ≈øay that there are many beyond the ≈øeas farre his betters, and much more learned, who haue decided this que≈øtion for vs against him, ≈øo that the conceit only of being an Arch-prie≈øt, or in authoritie, is left for them to iustifie the≈øe most iniurions calumniations against vs. If then they exact this obedience in Priests to the Arch-prie≈øt, in re≈øpect that he is a ≈øuperiour, and becau≈øe that he is a ≈øuperiour they imagine that euerie man who will not thinke as he thinketh, and do what he commaundeth is a Schi≈ømaticke, a rebell, factious, ≈øeditious, &c. The≈øe who are ≈øo ignorant must be taught, and ≈øuch as are contented at this time to make ≈øhewe of ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, mu≈øt be put in mind that authoritie is not an infallible rule of truth in all who haue authoritie, and con≈øequently that no man is bound in all things to beleeue or execute what euerie man in authoritie ouer him ≈øhall put vpon him. In how many things not onely Arch priests but their ≈øuperiours al≈øo the Archdeacons, and other of higher degree haue done ami≈ø≈øe, and ≈øwarued from the truth? and who vpon earth is warranted from erring but one, and not he in all things? how ab≈øurdly then ≈øhould this point be vrged that the Prie≈øts are Schi≈ømatickes, rebellious, &c. for not conforming them≈øelues in their vnder≈øtanding to an Archpriest? And if the ≈øimpler ≈øort of Catholiques cannot vnder≈øtand this rea≈øon ≈øufficiently grounded vpon too many examples recorded in all Eccle≈øiasticall Histories, we would demaund of them, when they are commaunded to doo that by ≈øuch as are in authoritie vpon their alleageance, which in con≈øcience they cannot doo, whether they be rebellious, factious, ≈øeditious, &c. in not obeying this commaundement? or by what rea≈øon they may in not obeying re≈øolue their con≈øciences, that they are not rebellious, &c?

Doubtle≈ø≈øe either they must confe≈ø≈øe that they are rebellious, &c. in not obeying the commaundment of tho≈øe who are in authoritie, or el≈øe that it is not a ≈øufficient proofe of rebellion that men do not in all things as others in authoritie commaund them, and to runne for refuge to ca≈øes, and particulars, is to flie touch for (hauing before ≈øpoken of this particular ca≈øe which is in question among vs) we pre≈ø≈øe now onely this point, that authoritie is not ≈øo infallible
a rule of truth in all to whom it is mo≈øt it stly deriued, as tho≈øe mu≈øt be condemned as factious, rebellious, ≈øediticus, ≈øchi≈ømatickes, &c. who will not conferme their vnder≈øtandings to their conceits, who are in authoritie becau≈øe they are in authoritie.

The≈øe points, and tho≈øe which hereafter will be touched, wee doo not ≈øet downe as men that would make ≈øheepe iudges of their pa≈øtours, but as men de≈øirous that their bretheren, and children, would not be ≈øo violently carried as they are, both against dutie, and charitie, but ≈øu≈øpend their iudgements in the≈øe matters, and ≈øo beare them≈øelues towards all, as they may hereafter make a good an≈øwere for their behauiour towards them, who haue after ≈øo deare a rate ≈øought to ≈øaue their ≈øoules, and now reque≈øt that their long ≈øufferance be no preiudice vnto them, nor warrant to loo≈ø≈øe tongues to enlarge them≈øelues with contumelious ≈øpeeches again≈øt them who≈øe cau≈øe the di≈øcour≈øes following wil both conuince all, who are de≈øirous not to be mi≈øled in a matter of ≈øo great con≈øequence, that it is iu≈øt, and that they haue al≈øo iu≈øt cau≈øe to publi≈øh the ≈øame for the better in≈øtruction of ≈øuch as with whom they may not be ≈øuffered or admitted to conferre about it, yet without touch of any more then the matter it ≈øelfe, and occa≈øions mini≈øtred doo mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily require.

closer.signed: Yours in all true hartie affection.

div.head: Certaine Con≈øiderations, to ≈øatisfie ≈øuch as either are, or may be, by any ≈øinister informations or ill conceipts incen≈øed against vs, or alienated from vs, becau≈øe we haue not yeelded our ≈øelues to the de≈øignments & wills of others, in ≈øub≈øcribing to this late authoritie.
div.p: FIr≈øt we de≈øire all good Catholickes to con≈øider indifferently, what we be, that deferre our ≈øub≈øcription to this authoritie; that we be Prie≈øts, & therfore in rea≈øon ≈øhould know, to what we were bouÃÑd in this ca≈øe. Againe, that our pre≈øent vocation, which is to labour eueÃÑ vnto death in ≈øauing of ≈øouls, and therefore not like to be altogether carele≈ø≈øe in matter of ≈øo great weight as this authoritie is pretended: of our own good, being ≈øo carefull of the good of others.

Further, that for many yeares we haue be≈øtowed our ≈øelues in this harue≈øt, and therefore in all likelyhood, ≈øhould ≈øomewhat knowe what thinges were mo≈øt conuenient for our ≈øelues and Country. Then that many of vs beeing in durance, haue for many yeares endured, and as we hope without reprehen≈øion, the bitter ≈øtormes of re≈øtraint and per≈øecution, and therfore in iu≈øtice ≈øhould de≈øerue at the lea≈øt, an ea≈øie & indifferent cen≈øure, of ≈øuch as either cannot,
or do not, heare vs an≈øwer for our ≈øelues. And that al≈øo ≈øome of our brethren as forward in di≈ølike and di≈øclaiming from ≈øuch proceedings as we be (if not more forward) haue ended their peregrination and troubles, with mo≈øt glorious martyrdome, giuing a great te≈øtimony thereby of their ≈øincere intentions in ≈øuch matters they tooke in hand, and leauing behinde them al≈øo, a good motiue vnto you, to cen≈øure and iudge no le≈ø≈øe of the intentions of others, who≈øe ca≈øes are the ≈øame with theirs, that they deale ≈øincerely and according to con≈øcience. And becau≈øe you cannot perhaps enter into a iu≈øt iudgement of the≈øe matters, not ≈øeeing into the depth, drift, and circum≈øtances thereof, wee de≈øire no more at your hands, but that you will as yet ≈øu≈øpend your iudgements of vs, and not vncharitably condemne vs, vntill you ≈øee the conclu≈øion and period of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, which will manife≈øt the truth of all our actions.

Secondly, we de≈øire you to con≈øider our pre≈øent e≈øtate in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe how we ≈øtand, that we haue and do vowe all obedience vnto Gods Church, and do acknowledge & embrace all authoritie lawfully proceeding from the See Apo≈øtolicke, and are mo≈øt readie to ≈øhewe all obedience therevnto, when we ≈øhall ≈øee and know by iu≈øt and ordinary Canonicall notice, what it is that the authoritie of that See exacteth at our hands, which no Chri≈øtian Catholicke can deny to be ≈øufficient, and as much as can in right and rea≈øon be de≈øired at our hands. And if we beleeue not euery Letter, Me≈ø≈øenger, or report,
onely deliuered vs by ≈øuch who are parties in this cau≈øe, and mai≈øter actors in erecting of this vnplea≈øing and obtruded authoritie, doo not blame vs; for we haue rea≈øon not to beleeue them in all things, much le≈ø≈øe in matters of ≈øuch weight and ≈øo daungerous, whom by experience we haue found difficient in many things, and whom we knowe to intend further matters hereby, then are ≈øeene or imagined of many. And yet in this, ≈øtand we but vpon our owne right, in not yeelding: becau≈øe we expect but ordinary authenticall proofe of ≈øo extraordinary iuri≈ødiction, neuer denied in matters of farre le≈ø≈øe moment and weight then this.

Thirdly, con≈øider what rea≈øon we haue to yeeld vnto this authoritie, not onely gotten by wrong and falce information and in≈øtance of the aduer≈øe part onely again≈øt our willes, without our knowledge; contrary to all equitie and iu≈øtice; but al≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed in ≈øuch ≈øort by them, that the ≈øuperiour mu≈øt needes remaine a punie, and inferiour to them, and by that meane be an in≈øtrument to execute what they ≈øhall thinke good or fit to be done; ≈øo that our ≈øuperiour being ≈øubiect vnto them, con≈øequently all we mu≈øt be their apprentizies, and ≈øtand at their commaund, which is to peruert all true order in Gods Church. For oftentimes, and by the late generall Councell of Trident, it is decreed, that the ≈øecular Cleargie ≈øhall haue power ouer the Religious, as to vi≈øite them, reforme and correct them, &c. as the Bi≈øhop dooth, but ≈øeldome or neuer hath the Religious Cleargie any iuri≈ødiction

And that the≈øe men haue ≈øought for ≈øuperioritie ouer vs their poore brethren, it is mo≈øt euident by their ≈øeueral enterpri≈øes to that end made amoÃÑg≈øt the pri≈øoners of Wisbiche: & that now al≈øo they ≈øeeke the ≈øame againe, and more generally by this new authoritie of the Arch-prie≈øt, is no le≈ø≈øe euident theÃÑ the former, to them that will ≈øee any thing; el≈øe, why ≈øhould they ≈øo earne≈øtly bu≈øie them≈øelues in a thing no whit at all concerning them, and much vnplea≈øing to others, as to prouide and place a Superiour ouer vs, who pertaine not to their charge, and that again≈øt our wills, and without our knowledge or coÃÑ ≈øent thereunto, not ≈øo much as demaunding our opinions thereof before hande. And when they haue done that, by fauours, per≈øwa≈øions, and increa≈øing of faculties, intyce and allure men to ratifie by ≈øub≈øcription, what they cunningly haue wrought vnderhaÃÑd; & to ≈øuch as refu≈øe to ≈øub≈øcribe, to threaten Excommunication, ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, taking away of faculties, and denounce them ≈øchi≈ømatikes, irregular, &c: and by Letters di≈øgrace them in places where they come, and giue warning of them as of ≈øchi≈ømatikes, & Excommunicate per≈øons. And more, to ≈øhewe their intentions in this matter, what intere≈øt they ≈øeeke and chalenge in this authoritie, though indeed nothing concerning them, becau≈øe a di≈øtinct ≈øocietie and bodie from vs; one of them in a Letter hee wrote vntoF. Garnet.
one that would not ≈øub≈øcribe, confe≈ø≈øeth & acknowledgeth, that what≈øoeuer is oppo≈øite to the Reuerend Arch-prie≈øt, mu≈øt of force, be con≈øequently, oppo≈øite & again≈øt them, which thing mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie import an extraordinary tye betweene the authoritie of the Arch-prie≈øt & them: either of the ≈øubordination of them vnto the Arch-prie≈øt, which they di≈øclaime from & deny, or coÃÑtrariwi≈øe of the Archprie≈øt to them, el≈øe how mu≈øt it of nece≈ø≈øitie follow, that he which is oppo≈øite vnto the Arch-prie≈øts authoritie, mu≈øt of force be oppo≈øite to them, as though a man might not re≈øi≈øt the Superiour of an order, but hee mu≈øt needs therby oppo≈øe him≈øelf again≈øt the whole body of an other order? Furthermore, if their intere≈øt were not great in this authoritie, why ≈øhould they be ≈øo vnwilling to procure, or ≈øuffer to be procured, ≈øome Bull or Breue, for the confirmation therof, that it might be an ab≈øolute and independent authoritie? but that hanging at the will and order of the Lorde Cardinall Protector only, they bearing a great ≈øway with him as we know they doo, may keep the Archprie≈øt in awe, that hee ≈øhall dare to doo nothing that may di≈øplea≈øe them, for feare they ≈øhould informe again≈øt him to the Cardinall, and ≈øo thru≈øt him out of office: which they could not doo, were his authoritie confirmed once by any Apo≈øtolicall writte: and this onely is the cau≈øe they loue not to heare of Bull or Brieue in this authoritie, if otherwi≈øe they can choo≈øe; for by this meanes the Arch-prie≈øt ≈øtanding in awe of them, we mu≈øt ≈øtand al≈øo at the reuer≈øion of their courte≈øies in any matter of que≈øtion or controuer≈øie

Fourthly con≈øider, that by yeelding vnto this pre≈øent authoritie erected and directed by them, we ≈øhall be drawne within the compa≈ø≈øe and perill of all plottes and actions what≈øoeuer, in matters of ≈øtate practi≈øed by them, or any of them, or hereafter ≈øhall be practi≈øed at any time by them, and ≈øo not we onely, but al≈øo ≈øuch with whom we ≈øhall conuer≈øe, and tho≈øe which ≈øhall concurre with vs in this action, ≈øhal be brought into more danger of the extremitie & rigour of the lawes, then otherwi≈øe we ≈øhould, in that the authoritie is alreadie thought by the Coun≈øell to be of purpo≈øe erected for the better effecting of ≈øuch de≈øignements; and ≈øo ≈øhall we, being brought within the compa≈ø≈øe of other mens actions, be hanged for kingdomes and matters of ≈øtate, and the glory of our cau≈øe therby dimini≈øhed, if not cleane extingui≈øhed, to ≈øatisfie other mens plea≈øures & ≈øerue their turnes. Be≈øides al this, by the opinioÃÑs of diuers men of iudgment in the lawes of our Country, this our ca≈øe may and will be drawne within the compa≈ø≈øe of an olde law enacted, a≈øwel by our Catholick Bi≈øhops & Prelates, as by the Prince, aboue 300. yeares agoe, vz. the lawe of Premunire; becau≈øe it is an externall iuri≈ødiction brought into this realme, again≈øt the will & notice of the Prince & Country, which made the late reuerend Bi≈øhop of Lincolne, Doctor Wat≈øon, to refu≈øe all externall iuri≈ødictioÃÑ offered him ouer his fellow pri≈øoners, although once he had lawfull Epi≈øcopall iuri≈ødiction within the Realme, and was vnlawfully depriued thereof.

Fitfthly con≈øider we be≈øeech you, for the ≈øatisfying of your con≈øciences in this mo≈øt vniu≈øt & ≈ølaunderous report made again≈øt vs of ≈øchi≈øme, that there can be no ≈øchi≈øme, where there is a re≈øigned will of obedience. We prote≈øt and vow all obedience due vnto Gods Church, and all her lawfull authoritie, and therefore can be made no ≈øchi≈ømatikes po≈ø≈øibly. If they vrge again≈øt vs that we obey not this authoritie: let them ≈øhewe vs that it is a lawfull act of the Church and we obey. If they tell vs of Letters from the Cardinal, we an≈øwer them, that no man is bound to beleeue the Cardinall him≈øelfe without Bull or Breue, in matters of ≈øo large coÃÑ≈øequence concerning the Church. What rea≈øon then is there that his graces bare Letters, the contents wherof drew on ≈øo general & extreme per≈øecution vpon our necks, ≈øhould be allowed of by vs, as a ≈øufficient proofe of the delegation? If they ≈øay that the Cardinall is a per≈øon of ≈øingular credit, and not to be di≈øtru≈øted, we an≈øwere them, that we impeach not his credit, ≈øtanding onely vpon our owne right and iu≈øtice for our full ≈øatisfaction from his holines, of his ab≈øolute will & plea≈øure herein, who≈øe lea≈øt commaund ≈øhall euer binde vs, though with hazard or lo≈ø≈øe of our liues. To thinke that his holine≈ø≈øe accounteth vs ≈øo ba≈øe and abiect a Cleargy, or ≈øo vnworthy members of Gods church, that we de≈øerue not his ordinary notice in matters of ≈øo great moment, which is but a coÃÑmoÃÑ proce≈ø≈øe in matters of farre le≈ø≈øe weight proceeding froÃÑ that See, were both in it ≈øelf ridiculous, & iniurious al≈øo to his holines. We could al≈øo vrge, that his hol. as yet hath
had no informatioÃÑ at all from vs, (our me≈ø≈øengers being preuented of audience, & clapped in clo≈øe pri≈øon by Father Per≈øons procurement) but onely froÃÑ them, who are but one and the aduer≈øe part in this controuer≈øie, which you know is again≈øt all right and equitie; and in which ca≈øe, being but a matter of fact, his Holi. for want of due & ≈øufficient information, may proceed with error, to the preiudice of the innocent part, although vnwillingly, and by him not intended: in which ca≈øe Appellations alwaies are permitted for further information in matters thus in que≈øtion. Con≈øider now ≈øincerely deare Catholickes, the≈øe rea≈øons propounded, and enter not too too ra≈øhly into condemnation of vs your ≈øpirituall Pa≈øtours, who haue alreadie in part, and are ≈øtil readie, to ≈øpend our bloud for your ≈øakes: but haue patience with vs a little, vntil you ≈øee the end of the≈øe matters, and the iudgements of his Holine≈ø≈øe herein, which we hope you ≈øhall ≈øhortly ≈øee, and perhappes in the ende, you ≈øhall finde that we, whom by ≈øini≈øter informations and ≈øugge≈øtions, you are now ready altogether to condemne, haue bene, and are your greate≈øt friends in with≈øtanding ≈øuche proceedings, as haply may concern your ≈øelues as neare, if not more neare, then vs, although you perceiue not, nor ≈øee ≈øo much. div.head: Other rea≈øons to the ≈øame purpo≈øe by another, vnder the forme of a Letter.
div.p: SYr, your priuate occa≈øions which you recommend to my care, I haue ≈øo tendered, that euery thing is as forward as any diligence of mine can ≈øet it, and in my la≈øt haue explaned to the full, the cour≈øe I tooke, which I tru≈øt is coÃÑformable to the directions you ≈øent mee, and will I hope haue the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe that both you and I de≈øire. The progre≈ø≈øe of the matter you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand as occa≈øion ≈øerueth. In the end of your Letter, you make mention of a diui≈øion lately growne among≈øt vs, who ≈øhould be examples of loue and vnion, and laments the bitter fruites ≈øprung thereof, as pernicious to many a Chri≈øtian ≈øoule. Whereof diuers friends of mine by name are charged to be ≈øome cau≈øe, for that they were not ready at fir≈øt to yeeld to the late authoritie of Mai≈øter Blackwell, nor as yet can be brought to acknowledge the ≈øame. Truly Syr, for that you are my friend, and I throughly acquainted with the origine & proce≈ø≈øe of the difference, I thought it my part, for your better information, & di≈øcharge of my blamele≈ø≈øe friends, briefly to ≈øet downe what is done in this matter, and vpon what ground, and then to leaue the cen≈øure of it to your prudent con≈øideration.

To build ≈øure, I lay this foundation; that it is neither pietie nor true obedience, at the fir≈øt ≈øight to admit any authoritie but ≈øuch as is orderly procured, and lawfully promulgated, in ≈øuch ≈øort that ≈øubiects
may remaine morally ≈øure, that it proceedeth froÃÑ the true fountaine of ≈øuperioritie truly enformed, which of it ≈øelfe is ≈øo manife≈øt that it needeth no proofe; for the contrary were to open the way to all forgeries and intru≈øions: and in fine, the ouerthrow of all Canonicall proceedings. Here hence followeth; that which true prudence and vertue doo dictate: that when any new and extraordinary authoritie is publi≈øhed, they whom it concerneth; before that by acceptance they approue it, ≈øhould of dutie looke and examine whether it be accompanied with the conditions aboue mentioned, and ≈øo admit or reiect it, as di≈øcretion & con≈øcience ≈øhall require. To the purpo≈øe, in both the≈øe conditions of lawfull authoritie, this we ≈øpeake of is feared to hault, and not without great pre≈øumption. And for that to handle both at large would exceed the limits of a Letter; and a defect in either, doth ≈øufficiently warrant their proceedings, I wil leaue the fir≈øt, (for that mu≈øt needs touch particular per≈øons and their actions: which without further occa≈øion and very iu≈øt, I am loath to do) and ≈øhew briefly how the manner of promulgation is in no way ≈øufficient, but rather full of ≈øu≈øpition, and giueth iu≈øt occa≈øion of di≈øtru≈øt.

And fir≈øt the credit of this promulgation, dooth wholly hang vpon their credits, who taketh authoritie vpon them, who for that they are parties in this action, may iu≈øtly be ≈øu≈øpected as partiall in their owne cau≈øe, which cannot choo≈øe but leaue the matter doubtfull in any indifferent mind: or ≈øuch at lea≈øt as no man is in con≈øcience bounde to beleeue.
Againe, put ca≈øe they were lawfulll promulgators, yet they bring nothing ≈øufficient to ordaine ≈øuch authoritie or iuri≈ødiction: to erect ≈øuch an authoritie, cannot be le≈ø≈øe then an expre≈ø≈øe commaundent of his Holine≈ø≈øe: and giuen for this particular purpo≈øe. And the ≈øame al≈øo authentically notified of al which the aduer≈øe part ≈øheweth nothing, for neither do they challenge any ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øe decree from his Holine≈ø≈øe: but onely order giuen to the Cardinal Protector, to take vp our controuer≈øies and iarres here, which is nothing to build ≈øuch an extraordinary ≈øuperioritie vpon: or if they did, we are not to giue full credit to the Cardinall his bare word, in a matter of ≈øo great weight: ≈øeeing that in ≈øuch bu≈øine≈ø≈øe he hath heretofore bene founde ouermuch affected to the one part, who haue their finger and hand in the≈øe affaires, and for this rea≈øon hath bene excepted again≈øt as vnfit to iudge in ≈øuch cau≈øes, that ≈øo neare concern tho≈øe parties as the≈øe things do, therefore the≈øe men demaund but right, if they require an authenticall in≈øtrument from his holines to ≈øpecifie his will herein, and in the meane while determine nothing, but re≈øt ready to imbrace what≈øoeuer his holines ≈øhal appoint.

Furthermore, there are now 8. or 9. moneths pa≈øt, ≈øith fir≈øt the authoritie was diuulged, & ≈øithence the lawfulnes therof, for the rea≈øons aboue mentioned and diuers others was doubted of, as not proceeding from his holines: yet the maintainers notwith≈øtanding the hotte, eager, & earne≈øt cour≈øe that they take in defence of it, would neuer obtaine the lea≈øt ticket,
or te≈øtimony vnder his holine≈ø≈øe hand, or directly from him, in confirmation of it: nor yet to notefie that euer any ≈øuche matter was appointed by him; knowing that ≈øuch a note woulde haue ended the whole controuer≈øie. And this maketh men in their mindes to que≈øtion with them≈øelues in this ≈øort: doo not the≈øe men by ordinary cour≈øe, monethly or oftner receiue Letters from Rome? hath not Cardinall Caietan weekely, yea daily acce≈ø≈øe to his holine≈ø≈øe as other Cardinalls haue? doo they want fauour with him who is wholly theirs; or his forwardnes to further that him≈øelfe hath either begunne or followed; and for the credit whereof, hee hath graunted what Letters them≈øelues would reque≈øt, and as effectuall as them≈øelues could drawe them? or would his holine≈ø≈øe refu≈øe to te≈øtifie that he is the appointer of this authoritie if it had proceeded froÃÑ him? No, no, there is cunning ≈øome where, which when matters are di≈øcouered will quickly appeare. And this is confirmed with another pre≈øumption of no le≈ø≈øe moment then the former. For when the≈øe friends of mine by vniforme con≈øent of many of their owne brethren, wi≈øe and learned, & the aunciente≈øt, had re≈øolued peaceably and quietly to ≈øend ouer to knowe the Popes plea≈øure in this matter, they ≈øent to the contrary part, to intreat theÃÑ to haue ≈øo much patience as to expect what an≈øwere the≈øe me≈ø≈øengers did receiue from his holine≈ø≈øe: and if matters proued to be ≈øo as they ≈øaid they were, then without further re≈øi≈øtance, euery body was ready to ioyne with them, & to re≈øi≈øt who≈øoeuer ≈øhould re≈øi≈øt them: and ≈øo the whole matter

But this ≈øo rea≈øonable a reque≈øt could not be heard, but as if they had feared ≈øome pre≈øent daunger now after ≈øending, they po≈øted about more earne≈øtly then euer before, ≈øend abroad papers, threaten excommunications, promi≈øe fauours, abu≈øe the laitie with infamous reports of their brethren, ≈øending into all quarters of the countrey to begge hands and ≈øub≈øcriptions: and where any for what iu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øoeuer did refu≈øe, their meanes open or ≈øecret were deui≈øed to ≈øupplant and di≈øgrace them, and accu≈øations forged to withdraw their lay friends, and con≈øequently their maintenance from them. Which mu≈øt needes con≈øtraine the wronged to defend and cleare them≈øelues euen with the ≈øame lay-friends; & ≈øo the matter grew to a coÃÑtention, & became publikely knowne amoÃÑg the Laitie, that women & childreÃÑ do tattle and de≈øcant euery where, and pa≈ø≈øe their cen≈øure therof. And what followeth of this, euery body may ≈øee, and it is too lamentable to ≈øpeake or write, what hurt our cau≈øe hath ≈øu≈øtained hereby.

But what good I pray you did the≈øe men pretend by ≈øo hurtfull a cour≈øe? Was the Pope ≈øo de≈øirous of thankes that it mu≈øt be procured with ≈øuch broyles? I cannot thinke it. Certes it maketh men iu≈øtly to mi≈øtru≈øt, that there is a further matter intended then in ≈øhewe they pretend: and that the≈øe hands & ≈øub≈øcriptions by ≈øuch meanes and ≈øo carefully procured to be ≈øent ouer in ≈øuch ha≈øte, mu≈øt ≈øerue to ≈øalue and
heale ≈øomewhat that is not ≈øound there: happily to draw the Pope to con≈øent to that which perchance he neuer heard or allowed of, and ≈øo heereby con≈øtraine men to put too their hands, ≈øaying it is his holine≈ø≈øe will they ≈øhould doo ≈øo, and there per≈øwade the Pope to allow of it, for that it is the Prie≈øts voluntary reque≈øt & ≈øute here. By which meanes no doubt but that they may ea≈øily procure the Popes confirmation; who is and hath bene ready to referre the choo≈øing of the ≈øuperiour to the Prie≈øts of England, as Father Per≈øons him≈øelfe can witne≈ø≈øe: which was the cau≈øe that at the beginning when ≈øuch a matter was propo≈øed to his holine≈ø≈øe: he would not proceed in it without they agreed & con≈øented al≈øo, as there is great rea≈øon for him. For who≈øe adui≈øe, con≈øent, and allowance, are required to the choo≈øing of a ≈øuperiour, if not theirs that are to obey and liue vnder the ≈øaid ≈øuperiour, when he is cho≈øen? do not the fellowes in euery hou≈øe in Oxenford (and according to the ≈øtatutes and foundation) choo≈øe and elect their head and Rector? And la≈øt of all, M. Blackwell him≈øelfe reported, that he had authoritie to excommunicate and command to the Court of Rome; which now belike, vpon better ≈øcanning of his authoritie, hee goes from. div.head: Mai≈øter Champneyes Letter of the ≈øame argument, to a Reuerend friend of his.
div.p:

div.p:
In the yeare of our Lord, 1600. vpon the third day of May, it was propo≈øed to the facultie of the Diuines of the Vniuer≈øitie of Paris, that by the Letters of a mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Cardinall, an Eccle≈øia≈øticall Superiour was con≈øtituted in a certaine Kingdome, with the tytle and dignitie of an Arch-prie≈øt, to haue authoritie and iuri≈ødiction ouer all other Prie≈øts re≈øiding in that Kingdome. This Cardinall did al≈øo declare in tho≈øe his Letters, that he did it according to the will and good liking of the Pope. Notwith≈øtanding many of the≈øe Prie≈øts refu≈øed to ≈øub≈øcribe to the authoritie of the ≈øaid Arch-prie≈øt, before he had obtained Letters from the See Apo≈øtolicke conteining the tenour of his confirmation, as well becau≈øe that kind of gouernment was altogether new in Gods Church, and hetherto neuer heard of, that an Arch-Prie≈øt ≈øhould haue charge of a whole kingdome, and ≈øuch iuri≈ødiction ouer euery Prie≈øt in that Realme:

div.p: This we ≈øhewed to our Arch-prie≈øt, who, that he might leaue no way vnattempted to iniurie vs, prohibited all Prie≈øts vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion from the Altar, and lo≈ø≈øe of all their faculties, and Laie-men, vnder paine of being interdicted ip≈øefacto, to defend directly, or indirectly, the cen≈øure & opinion of the Doctors of Paris, whether it were giuen by true information or otherwi≈øe: which was not onely an intollerable iniurie vnto vs, prohibiting again≈øt the law of nature from defending our good names, but al≈øo an ab≈øurd indignitie again≈øt ≈øo famous an Vniuer≈øitie. haue ta≈øted abundantly; they haue giuen too too pregnant proofes of their further de≈øignements, if ≈øo that they can effect their purpo≈øe. But verily their proceedings haue hitherto bene farre different, not onely from theirs who haue planted and watered the vineyard of Gods Church from the beginning, but al≈øo froÃÑ theirs to whom before all other men, we ought mo≈øt to attribute that hope we haue of the recouery of our poore Country to the Catholicke faith; namely Cardinall Allane, of mo≈øt holie and happie memorie, who≈øe life if it had plea≈øed God to haue lent vs till this day, we ≈øhould haue had, if not in ≈øome ≈øort, a flouri≈øhing Church, yet a Church at lea≈øt without ≈øuch enormous di≈ø≈øention, ≈øtrife, and debate; a Church full of true ≈øimplicitie, religious zeale, and fraternall charitie; for ≈øuch a one (God concurring to his holy endeuours) hee planted, and vntill his dying day, kept & con≈øerued. But

God pardon the cau≈øers thereof, and grant vs perfect peace and brotherly charitie: Vt omnes cogno≈øcant qu√≤d di≈øcipuli Christi ≈øimus. That all men may know vs to be the di≈øciples of Chri≈øt.

Thus good Syr, haue I laid downe vnto you the whole grounds of the crimes, wherof both my ≈øelfe and diuers others of our brethren are accu≈øed. I rereferre the matter to your iudgement, to di≈øcerne whether we be guiltie of them or no. If you doubt of the truth of my relation, I de≈øire none other triall then the te≈øtimonie of mine accu≈øers; who if they denie any one word that I haue vttered by way of narration, I can ea≈øily procure ≈øuch proofe thereof, as they ≈øhall not denie, vnle≈ø≈øe they will denie them≈øelues. If my deductions, arguments, or ≈øuppo≈øitions, v≈øed in yeelding rea≈øon for our not admitting M. Blackwells authoritie vpon the onely receit of Cardinall Caietaines Letters, and that for ≈øo doing, we incurred no note either of ≈øchi≈øme, or di≈øobedience to his holine≈ø≈øe; if they I ≈øay need any proofe, I will vndertake to make them mo≈øt euident.

Wherefore according to the≈øe grounds, I humbly be≈øeech you to pa≈ø≈øe your opinion, and yeeld your iudgement of our cau≈øe. And if the grounds prooue true, your iudgement conformable therevnto, may remaine firme: but if they prooue otherwi≈øe, your iudgement notwith≈øtanding ≈øhall not be faultie; for he that iudgeth according to his euidence, is not culpable
