This good Sir, I reque≈øt, becau≈øe I de≈øire to know your opinion of our cau≈øe, which if you giue according to the≈øe grounds, I ≈øhal ea≈øily vnder≈øtand whether you wil condemne or cleare mee & my brethren of the crimes obiected; for I am ≈øure I haue not erred in declaring the ≈øtate of the matter.

If this which I haue ≈øaid be not ≈øufficient for your full ≈øatisfaction; I hope it wil ≈øuffice at lea≈øt to ≈øu≈øpend your iudgement of vs, vntill further triall be had of our cau≈øe; which being had in any indifferent manner, and if we being conuicted, do not acknowledge our fault, and make competent ≈øatisfaction, then do not ≈øpare to account of vs as Heathens & Publicans. But our aduer≈øaries purpo≈øe not to put the matter to any indifferent tryall, or to ende it by any equall meanes, but to decide it by ≈øtrong hand, might, and violence; by perpetuall oppre≈ø≈øing vs with infamous ≈ølaunders of ≈øchi≈øme, faction, and the like; thereby to depriue, if it can be, our brethren abroad, of all conuenient entertainment, and to debarre vs in pri≈øon of nece≈ø≈øary reliefe, to the ende that nece≈ø≈øitie may compell vs to yeeld to their de≈øires: the inequalitie of which proceedings, I be≈øeech you with indiffereÃÑ cy to coÃÑ≈øider. Sometime it is ≈øeen, that a partie wilfully bent to contend, is iu≈øtly compelled to admit an equall compremi≈øe, and to ≈øtand to the arbitrement of an indifferent Iudge: but it was neuer ≈øeene where iu≈øtice and con≈øcience ruled; and muche le≈ø≈øe among≈øt ≈øuch as ought to be the rule of other mens con≈øciences, that the partie willing to ≈øtand to anie indifferent tryall, ≈øhould bee compelled
by violence, to agree vnto the de≈øire of his aduer≈øary, how iu≈øt or vniu≈øt ≈øoeuer it be, and that without any further ≈øentence, but onely becau≈øe his aduer≈øary mu≈øt haue his will.

Good Sir, we are heere in this place, diuers in great want, in ≈øo much, that be≈øides our debts to the keeper, we haue not to defend vs from the iniury of the winter weather: whereof that you may haue ≈øome ≈øpecial ta≈øte, I doo you to vnder≈øtand, that ≈øince Trinitie Terme, wee haue receiued no more from London, from whence the chiefe≈øt part of our reliefe commeth, then will ≈øuffice for three weekes charges with him that can husband his matters be≈øt. And this ≈øhalbe ≈øufficient to in≈øinuate vnto you our wants, hoping that as opportunitie ≈øerueth, you will concurre to the relieuing thereof; confidently hoping withal, that God for who≈øe cau≈øe we ≈øuffer, not onely of the coÃÑmon aduer≈øary, but al≈øo of tho≈øe who ought to be our friends, wil giue vs patieÃÑce what≈øoeuer cro≈ø≈øes befal vs, to beare them to the end. For mine owne part, they may by their violent proceedings, make me yeeld my breath and life, which by Gods grace, I ≈øhall if need require, willingly ≈øacrifice for the defence of iu≈øtice, equitie, and mine owne innocencie: but my con≈øent to the≈øe vniu≈øt dealings, by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, they ≈øhall neuer extort out of me.

If any one to whom you ≈øhall thinke good to impart this (as I am not again≈øt the imparting it to any, ≈øo that you keepe the originall your ≈øelfe) ≈øhall vndertake to improue me of any vntruth: I will either ≈øatisfie his obiections euen to your own iudgement,
or el≈øe I will acknowledge mine errour.

Take this, good Sir, for a ta≈øte of our internall and dome≈øticall troubles, wherewith I imagine you are not much acquainted, and therefore are you wor≈øe affected to our cau≈øe: and as you ≈øhall giue me hereafter occa≈øion, you ≈øhall vnder≈øtand more; for this is but a ≈ømall thing in re≈øpect of that which this matter affordeth. But I feare I haue bene too tedious in this ≈øo di≈øgu≈øtfull a di≈øcour≈øe; but let, I pray you, the hard tearmes my good name is brought into, plead my pardon for my tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and the equitie of my Plea, procure me your fauour, and ≈øo in all humble ≈øort I take my leaue.

closer.signed: Yours euer in all true Chri≈øtian affection, Anthony Champney.

postscript.p:
SIr, if you do not con≈øider diligently the haynousPo≈øt ≈øcriptuÃÑ. enormitie of ≈øchi≈øme impo≈øed vpon me, you will peraduenture condemne me of too much preci≈øene≈ø≈øe, if not of contention, for labouring to defend my ≈øelfe from the note thereof; and will thinke that I ought rather to ≈øuffer ≈øome ≈ømall infamie, then by oppo≈øing my ≈øelfe ≈øo earne≈øtly, to repell the ≈øame, to procure a further breach between mine accu≈øers and my ≈øelfe, to both our harmes, and to the offence of others. But if you con≈øider fir≈øt, to admit the infamy of this ≈ølaunder, (though it were of it ≈øelfe but ≈ømall) were in ≈øome ≈øort to giue occa≈øion to mine accu≈øers, to heape vpon my head greater wrongs hereafter,
(for he that will offer wrong in one thing, will do the like in an other if occa≈øion ≈øerue) you ≈øhall finde it to be neither wi≈øedome nor pietie, to giue place to ≈øuch beginnings. Secondly, the condition of mine e≈øtate requiring a mo≈øt entire fame, I ≈øhould both wrong my ≈øelfe, and ≈ølaunder my function, if I ≈øhould admit any blemi≈øh or blotte therein, which I may by mine owne endeuour wipe away: and therefore to purcha≈øe peace at ≈øuch a price, I hold it not lawfull: for Non e≈øt faciendum malum vt eremat bonum. Euill is not to be done that good may en≈øue. And as S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith: Qui famam ≈øuam negligit, crudelis e≈øt. Hee that neglecteth his good name is cruell. But if thirdly you coÃÑ≈øider the intrin≈øical enormitie of this crime, you will ea≈øily excu≈øe mine endeuour in clearing my ≈øelf therof, from all note of contention. For among≈øt all other ≈øinnes again≈øt our neighbour, ≈øchi≈øme is the greate≈øt: and the pennalties which the Church hath alwaies inflicted on ≈øuch as haue bene guiltie therof, proue the ≈øame; to weet, excommunication and ≈øeperation from all v≈øe of Sacraments, as appeareth by diuers auncient Canons, & al≈øo in Bulla caenae: which being graunted, nece≈ø≈øarily followeth heynous ≈øacriledge, committed by the mini≈øtratioÃÑ of Sacraments, and the fru≈øtrating of all confe≈ø≈øions made to all ≈øuch as they do terme ≈øchi≈ømatikes. For my fuller acquittance of which ≈øchi≈øme, in one word I ≈øay, that if I be a ≈øchi≈ømaticke, Clemens the eight is a ≈øchi≈ømaticke; for his wil is my wil, both in this and all other things pertaining to Eccle≈øia≈øticall gouernment, and for mine obedience and ≈øubiection to him in the ≈øame,
as hetherto by Gods grace I haue not, ≈øo God a≈ø≈øi≈øting me hereafter, I will not refu≈øe to yeeld my life, if at any time it be exacted.

Peraduenture Sir you will maruell, how I dare attempt to ≈øay thus much in mine own and my bretherens defence, our Arch-prie≈øt hauing vnder paine of ≈øu≈øpen≈øion, commanded the contrary. But you may vnder≈øtand, that this commandement cannot bee of force (and therefore not to be re≈øpected) for diuers cau≈øes. And chiefly, for that the law of nature graunteth ab≈øolute freedome to euery one to defend him≈øelfe and his goods either of fame or fortune, and to labour by lawfull meanes, to recouer them being vniu≈øtly taken from him. For which cau≈øe it is an intollerable errour, annullating any iuridicall ≈øentence to forbid a man to defend him≈øelfe. Silue≈øter verb. Excom. 2. num. 1. & 16. Our Arch-prie≈øts prohibitory cen≈øures therefore in this ca≈øe, are euen by the law of nature made void. And if he ≈øay that we haue ≈øuffred no wroÃÑg by the lo≈ø≈øe of our good names, but that we haue iu≈øtly de≈øerued the infamy of ≈øchi≈øme, it wil not ≈øerue his turn, for he being in this ca≈øe, a party ≈øubiect to triall, and therfore no Iudge to di≈øcerne whether we haue ≈øuffered wrong or no, his ≈øentence or opinioÃÑ herein can be of no more force, then his ought to be, who hauing taken away an other mans goods, ≈øaith that he hath not wronged him, and therfore forbiddeth him to pro≈øecute the ca≈øe again≈øt him, vnder paine of a greater di≈øplea≈øure: for this is iu≈øt our ca≈øe. I might ≈øay much more in this matter, but I haue bin too long already, and I hope this will ≈øuffice for this point: and ≈øo once againe I take my leaue.

div.head: THE COPIE OF A LETTER written by F. Rob. Par≈øons the Ie≈øuite, 9. Octob. 1599. to M. D. Bi≈øh: and M. Ch. two bani≈øhed and configned Prie≈øts, the one in Fraunce, the other in Lorraine, by the ≈øugge≈øtions of F. Par≈øons, for pre≈øuming to goe to Rome in the affaires of the Catholicke Church.

opener.salute: To my very louing friend M. W. Bi≈øh, Prie≈øt: giue the≈øe.

div.p:
¬∂MAi≈øter Bi≈øh, it being now diuers moneths ≈øince you departed from hence, and no one Letter appearing yet from you: or froÃÑ your friend M. Ch. it made vs maruaile, con≈øidering your promi≈øes at your departures; and ≈øome began to ≈øu≈øpect (that which I feare me will proue too true) that you were fallen into that temptation which each man did ea≈øily fore≈øee heere before you went hence; and I many times foretold you al≈øo, to wit, that you hauing receiued euil ≈øucce≈ø≈øe here in your iourney by your owne defaults, and going among men that would & mu≈øt of courte≈øie bemone the ≈øame (for who will to your faces ≈øeeme to like of it, or ≈øay you haue de≈øerued it)
you would be in daunger thereby to chaunge your good mindes that here you ≈øhewed, of acknowledging your owne errours: and for excu≈øe thereof, would laie the fault where it is not, and ≈øo make po≈øteriora peiora prioribus.

¬∂ And albeit at that time you ≈øaide you would neuer fal into this pitte, yet I doubt me you haue not performed it; for by a ≈øtale Letter which I receiued this weeke from you, written ≈øoone after your arriuall at Paris (to wit, the 11. of Iune) I perceiue you were ≈ølidden much forward, ≈øeeing you ≈øay, you cannot but tell me of the great di≈ølike which ordinarily all ≈øorts of men haue of your impri≈øonment and hard v≈øage heere in Rome. And moreouer, you ≈øay that euerie one crieth out again≈øt it, although you v≈øe all the modifications which in truth and equitie you may. And theÃÑ further, you wi≈øh me to preueÃÑt in time the odious name of a rigorous & ≈øterne gouernour, and not by colourable words, but by effectual deeds; and that it is a coro≈øiue vnto you, that tho≈øe goodly giftes (≈øo you write) which God hath be≈øtowed vpon me, ≈øhould by the alienations of our Country-mens affections from mee, be made le≈ø≈øe able to do our Country that good which all de≈øire.

¬∂ All which words, and ≈øome other in the ≈øame Letter, (though the≈øe are the principall) doo ≈øhewe a great chaunge in you, from that you ≈øhewed here at your departure: which thing notwith≈øtanding moueth not me ≈øo much for your owne per≈øons (con≈øidering the roote from whence it groweth, and that griefe mu≈øt haue ≈øome vtterance) as that which is
written hither diuers waies, and by diuers per≈øons of credit, of other mens ≈øpeeches (vpon your reports and complaints by all likelyhood) touching your ≈øuperiours al≈øo; for by this ≈øame Po≈øte, and with your Letter came another, of our friend M. D. C. which you do al≈øo mention, and he ≈øaith that your friends (though he commend your owne moderation) do crie out and complaine of ≈øingular iniu≈øtice done vnto you: and that you could not be heard iuridic√®, nor haue your Proctors, or proceed in your proce≈ø≈øe as Iewes & Turkes and common malefactors are permitted.

¬∂ But another friend yet writeth more largely from Flaunders, by the Ordinary of this weeke, that pa≈ø≈øing of late by tho≈øe partes where M. Ch. re≈øideth (though he talked not with him≈øelfe) yet he reporteth that others crie out in like manner, being ≈øtirred vp as hee ≈øaith (for I will relate his owne words) by the grieuous complaints of M. Ch. who threateneth to ≈øet downe in Print the whole ≈øtorie of your v≈øage here; to make it knowne thereby, as he writeth, both in England and el≈øe-where, how Prie≈øts be receiued by his holine≈ø≈øe, that come from Catholiques to di≈øclo≈øe their griefes vnto him; and that hee doth not beare him≈øelfe as a common Father, but as partiall for Ie≈øuits, preuented by them, to the ruine of poore Prie≈øts; and that in Turkie they ≈øhould haue bin v≈øed no wor≈øe: and that he and you, ≈øeeing how matters pa≈ø≈øed, determined neuer vnto this day, to open vnto his holine≈ø≈øe, nor vnto the Protector, the true cau≈øes of your ≈øending, nor what errand you had, which
≈øhould haue bene deliuered to his holine≈ø≈øe onely. Moreouer hee ≈øaith, they lament bitterly the poore e≈øtate of Catholiques, who at home are per≈øecuted, and abroad cannot be heard when they ≈øend to open their griefes to him that ought to giue eare to all as a common Father, and that the Colledge at Rome is brought into a Spani≈øh and Italian gouernment, F. Par≈øons bearing him≈øelfe not as a Country-man, but Italianated; that men will labour in Englande that none do ≈øend ouer their ≈øonnes to be brought vp in it, for that it is not fit for Engli≈øh natures; that it will neuer be well in England vntill Ie≈øuites be recalled: Saltem tempore per≈øecutionis, &c.

¬∂ The≈øe, and many more points like vnto the≈øe, our fore≈øaid friend writeth, which for breuitie I doo omit, and the≈øe I would pretermit al≈øo without any an≈øwere at all, for ≈øo much as toucheth my ≈øelfe and our ≈øocietie (who≈øe deeds doo ≈øpeake of them≈øelues again≈øt all calumniation of wordes) but that tho≈øe thinges which touch our ≈øuperiours (his holine≈ø≈øe e≈øpecially, & our two Cardinall Protectors that had your matter in hearing by his holine≈ø≈øe Commi≈ø≈øion) may not be let pa≈ø≈øe, to run with ≈øo fal≈øe and iniurious reports, again≈øt all truth and equitie.

¬∂ Wherefore I mu≈øt needes recount with you the ≈øtorie briefly againe, for recalling you to better memorie if you forget, or conuenting your con≈øciences, if you or your fellow vpon pa≈ø≈øion doo ouerla≈øh; or at lea≈øt wi≈øe for ≈øatisfying in part our fore≈øaid two friends that haue written to mee of the≈øe complaints, by who≈øe hands I meane that this Letter ≈øhal
goe open for them to read, and after to ≈øend or deliuer vnto you: and I pray you al≈øo, that M. Ch. may haue a ≈øight or copie of the ≈øame, when you haue vewed it; together with ≈øome good temperate coun≈øell from you: and he is thought to haue more need of it by his hotte nature knowne, and by the reports that come daily froÃÑ his parts of like ≈øpeeches to the≈øe before ≈øpecified: which if once they come to the eares of them whom mo≈øt they concerne, they may chance to bee called by them to further examination, which I would gladly were preuented if it may bee.

¬∂ Fir≈øt then touching the matter it ≈øelfe, you cannot but remember that at your arriuall at Rome, vpon the 11. of December, 1598. (if I mi≈øtake not) after friendly offer to entertaine you in this Colledge for the dayes of Ho≈øpitalitie accu≈øtomed (though the cau≈øe of your comming to Rome, was knowne to bee farre other then the rule appointeth for ≈øuch as are ≈øo to be entertained) I tolde you at large how all matters ≈øtood, and how his holine≈ø≈øe then in Ferrara, hauing beene enformed by his Nuntios in Fraunce and Flaunders of your comming, was much offended therewith, and meant to put you in pri≈øon if you had commen to Ferrara, as appeared by a Letter of F. Bellarmino, now Cardinall, which I had ≈øent pre≈øently to Flaunders to meet you there, if you had pa≈ø≈øed that way from Fraunce, as it was thought you would: and by that Letter appeareth al≈øo that I had not enformed again≈øt you, ≈øeeing that his holine≈ø≈øe willed the Father to write to Rome, to know my opinion
of you, as by the original Letter yet here extant is manife≈øt; and the cau≈øe of his holine≈ø≈øe offence again≈øt you was, that hauing bin vexed for more then three yeares together immediately before, with ≈øuch a ≈øedition of Engli≈øhmen heere in Rome and in Flaunders, as had vtterly wearied him & this whole Court, and had ≈øcandalized all Chri≈øtendome, and highly di≈øcredited our Engli≈øh Nation and Catholique cau≈øe; and hauing after all waies of examination and trials, both by vi≈øitations, commi≈ø≈øions, memorials, and the like, found no other ground of all the≈øe ≈øtirs, clamours, & tempe≈øts, but only enuie, emulation, and di≈ø≈øolute humours, of loo≈øe behauiour in ≈øome, and no one point proued, nor able to be proued of the manifold ≈ølaunders which were exhibited in the≈øe tumults, again≈øt mo≈øt innocent men of the Societie, who had bene the be≈øt friends of the trouble≈øome: his holine≈ø≈øe re≈øolued to make an end at la≈øt, and ≈øo did in this Colledge, by puni≈øhing the principall; and how much the finger of Almightie God a≈ø≈øi≈øted him in this action, the ble≈ø≈øed fruites that haue en≈øued ≈øince, of peace, vnion, mode≈øtie, ≈øpirit, learning, and deuotion in the≈øe youthes, haue euidently declared: whereby they haue regained againe a great part of that e≈øtimation and good opinion, which the former had lo≈øt by their contrary vices.

¬∂ Moreouer, his holine≈ø≈øe perceiuing that the tayle of this matter had pa≈ø≈øed al≈øo into England, and began to worke the ≈øame effects there, vpon the ≈øame grounds of emulation & ≈øeditious ≈øpirits, he thought no better way to cut off the ≈øaid emulation, then to
appoint a ≈øubordination among Prie≈øts them≈øelues; which Ie≈øuites e≈øpecially among other Catholiques their friends, haue demaunded for many yeares together, thereby to deliuer them≈øelues from all ≈øhewe of that calumniation v≈øed to bee laide again≈øt them, that they would gouerne the Prie≈øts again≈øt their wils; and hereof proceed the long deliberation of his holine≈ø≈øe: together with the Cardinals, not onely Protectors, but al≈øo of the Inqui≈øition, whether it were be≈øt to appoint at the beginning, a Bi≈øhop or Arch-prie≈øt: which deliberation endured aboue a yeare together; and in the meane ≈øpace his holine≈ø≈øe tooke information al≈øo ≈øufficient, about the per≈øon mo≈øt fit for the office, and that from Prie≈øts of England, though not perhappes from you, as it was not nece≈ø≈øary; and in the ende, re≈øolued vppon the dignitie and man that you knowe. Which beeing admitted and appointed mo≈øt willingly by al the body, both of Prie≈øts and other Catholiques in England, and abroad al≈øo, you only, and very fewe others ioyned with you (as heere was proued by your account) oppo≈øed your ≈øelues, and not expecting to bring any matter of ≈øub≈øtance again≈øt his gouernmeÃÑt that was appointed for your ≈øuperiour, you ≈øub≈øtracted your ≈øelues from his obedience, and gaue occa≈øion for others to do the like: and con≈øequently, to cau≈øe a mo≈øt perillous ≈øchi≈øme and ≈øedition among≈øt Catholicques in our Countrey; which his holine≈ø≈øe fore≈øeeing, meant to re≈øtraine you at your comming: but yet to heare and examine all that you brought, as afterwards he did, and you do greatly wrong him, if
you report the contrary.

¬∂ Well, all this and much more I tolde you at your comming hither, and that not in colourable, but in plaine and friendly words: offering you further, to be a meane notwith≈øtanding, to end all quietly, and with your credits, if you would. For ≈øaid I, heere bee now the immediate ≈øuperiours of both Prie≈øts and Ie≈øuites: to wit, the Protector of our Nation, and the Generall of the Societie, let vs deale with them to end all matters, and to ≈øend you backe againe with your honour; and with Letters both to the Arch-prie≈øt and ≈øuperiour of the Fathers, to giue you any ≈øatisfaction rea≈øonable, and remedie any thing that is ami≈ø≈øe, concerning any per≈øons of each of tho≈øe bodies. This point I dealt with you mo≈øt effectually many times, both in ≈øeuerall, and iointly, while you remained in this Colledge, & after whiles you laie in the Citie before your re≈øtraint, but could neuer obtaine anie inclination in you to the ≈øame, but that you would needs impugne both the authoritie and man by his holine≈ø≈øe appointed; wherein I euer told you plainly, that both I and all others that loued vnion, and re≈øpected with due obedience our ≈øuperiours ordination, mu≈øt needs be again≈øt you. And the ≈øame told you al≈øo, M. D. Haddock, M. Martin Array, and Prie≈øts of your owne coate that laie here, and are your auncients, both in your owne order, and their trauells in England; and the verie ≈øame we made you to ≈øee to be the iudgements of the graue≈øt of our Nation, in Flaunders, and other places, and e≈øpecially in England: from whence I a≈ø≈øure my
≈øelfe I ≈øhewed you fir≈øt and la≈øt neare two hundreth names of Prie≈øts writing & ≈øub≈øcribing again≈øt you: & you afterwards vpon your oathes could not name a dozen to be for you, as yet appeareth in the Regi≈øter.

¬∂ Thus then ≈øtanding your ca≈øe and ob≈øtinacie, and hauing bin exhorted both by the Cardinall Caietane Protector, and by Cardinall Burghe≈øe Vice-Protector, to de≈øi≈øt froÃÑ your enterpri≈øe of contradiction, without foundatioÃÑ at all (as after appeared, and then was ≈øu≈øpected) his holine≈ø≈øe after ≈øeuenteene daies of your per≈øi≈øting or thereabout, willed you to be retyred to ≈øome place of cu≈øtodie, in re≈øpect of your offence, and there your allegations to be examined, whether they were worth the handling or no; which comming to my knowledge, I entreated rather that your retirement might be with ≈øecrecie in this Colledge, then with more infamie in anie other place, though I ea≈øilie fore≈øawe what thankes I was like to haue for my labour; but I did it for him by whom I caÃÑnot lee≈øe, as I did al≈øo the re≈øt; to wit, in giuing you of the be≈øt chambers in the hou≈øe, in cheri≈øhing you gratis, in vi≈øiting you often, and making each of you good new gownes for the winter; in giuing you a Father to be your Notarie gratis, & procuring your Iudge to come to the Colledge and lie here to examine you: with commoditie, which otherwi≈øe would haue co≈øt you much money, and manie painfull iournies about the ≈øtreets, and other incommodities, which now you litle con≈øider.

¬∂ Well, your examination and retirement, endured
three moneths or more; you had time & commoditie to ≈øay or write what you woulde, yea you were willed vpon your oaths to ≈øay what you could, and all that you ≈øaid is written, and you did ≈øweare you had no more to ≈øay of moment in all matters handled, as appeareth by the Records: and all that you ≈øaid was con≈øidered of maturelie, as wel by your Iudge that was a Lawier, as al≈øo by the two Cardinalls, the one a Diuine, the other a Lawier; who to the ende they might be ≈øure to heare all, and ≈øatisfie both you and them≈øelues, did come in per≈øon one day to the Colledge to examine you, and to heare redde in your pre≈øence, all that you had ≈øaid and depo≈øed, or could ≈øay: and after this, yet ≈øtaied they diuers weekes to enforme his holine≈ø≈øe, before they gaue ≈øentence in your cau≈øe.

¬∂ And how then can it be ≈øaid with anie colour that you had wrong, and that you had le≈ø≈øe iu≈øtice here, then is permitted to Turkes and Iewes? How can his holine≈ø≈øe and the Cardinalls be accu≈øed of partiall dealing? ≈øeeing they heard all you could ≈øay, and would haue had you ≈øaie more, and were a≈øhamed to finde you to haue comen ≈øo long a iourney with ≈øo little to ≈øaie, finding you al≈øo not to haue brought with you, ≈øo much as anie one Letter of credence from anie communitie or priuate per≈øon, in ≈øuch forme as might giue credit, for that tho≈øe little open ≈øcrowles that you brought without ≈øub≈øtance or forme of anie Commi≈ø≈øion, were a≈øhame to looke vpon? Your ≈øecret memorialls al≈øo that you had ≈øet downe here in M. Ch. owne hand, to exhibit to his
holine≈ø≈øe, of your mo≈øt ≈øecret bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, are here to be ≈øeene; and the Iudge, Cardinalls, and perhappes his holi. al≈øo, haue had the view of them, & haue found them of no more weight then the re≈øt; and how then is it ≈øaid that you kept your chiefe me≈ø≈øage to your ≈øelues and di≈øclo≈øed it not? what me≈ø≈øage could this be? or from whom? for of the Ie≈øuites and of the Archipresbyter you ≈øaid your fill, and were willed vpon your oaths to ≈øaie more, if you had anie to ≈øaie, in that or in any other points. And as for tho≈øe prie≈øts that ≈øent you, they were verie fewe as appeared; and I ≈øhewed you well neere twentie times as manie names of the ≈øame order again≈øt you: who te≈øtifie al≈øo for all Catholiques which deale with them, to be of the ≈øame opinion, and to haue mi≈øliked your iournie and cau≈øe, and dete≈øted the ≈øchi≈øme that thereof in≈øued.

¬∂ And how then doo men vpon this little part or faction of yours v≈øe tho≈øe prai≈øes, that the Catholiques are intollerablie afflicted, being per≈øecuted at home, and cannot be heard abroad? Who are the≈øe Catholiques? or what audience is denied to them? If we compare the per≈øecution of tho≈øe Prie≈øtes at home, by the heretiques that hold with you, or with the Arch-prie≈øt and Ie≈øuites, it is ea≈øily ≈øeene who are mo≈øt per≈øecuted and hated by the Councell of England; and if anie complaine that your ≈øide hath not bene heard by his holine≈ø≈øe, let his holi. patience for three or foure whole yeares together, in dooing nothing el≈øe but hearing & examining of their impertinent clamours in this Citie, deliuer him from that
vniu≈øt calumniation. And ≈øo much of our Superiours.

¬∂ As touching my ≈øelfe, my defence ≈øhall be much ≈øhorter; you adui≈øe me to preuent the odious name of a ≈øterne and rigorous Gouernour, and that not by colourable words, but by effectual deeds, and I embrace the aduice mo≈øt willinglie, for indeed I finde great aver≈øion in my nature of all the≈øe points you name; I meane, of ≈øterne, rigorous, colourable, and no le≈ø≈øe perhaps from Couernour, which euer I haue fled and avoided, vntill now, that perforce I am con≈øtrained to haue the gouernment of this hou≈øe; wherein yet I ≈øuppo≈øe, that I may haue as many witne≈ø≈øes as here be inhabitants, that my proceeding, is neither ≈øterne, rigorous, nor colourable with them, & with you I am ≈øure I neuer v≈øed it, as may appeare by that which before hath bene ≈øaide, of my plaine, reall, & friendlie dealing in your affaire; and I would aske but one example to be alleadged and proued to the contrarie, as I could alledge manie in my behalf, and one ≈øomewhat notorious ≈øince your departure, of one M. Shawe a Prie≈øt, who hauing fallen fowly in England, & railed afterwards egregiou≈øly again≈øt the Societie (as hee had done al≈øo here in Rome fir≈øt before his going into England, and commonly the≈øe matters goe together) yet comming hither of late, and being in great mi≈øerie, both ≈øpiritually and temporally, and in daunger to di≈øpaire, and to lie God knoweth how long in the Inqui≈øition, I haue comforted and a≈ø≈øi≈øted him in this Colledge, as if he had bene mine owne brother, and this for manie daies
together, procuring him al≈øo a good and fauourable di≈øpatch, and afterwards to bee placed in a good Church vnder religious men in Naples, where he liueth with great contentment to him≈øelfe, and edification hitherto of others.

¬∂ Sir I mu≈øt needs ≈øay here with the Apo≈øtle: Factus ≈øum in≈øipiens, ≈øed vos me coegi≈øtis: to ≈øhewe my ≈øelfe to be neither ≈øterne, nor rigorous, nor colourable, I am forced to ≈øpeake of that I would not. It may bee you doo mi≈ølike in me my firme ≈øtanding again≈øt the trouble≈øome of this hou≈øe fir≈øt, and again≈øt you, and your companioÃÑ afterward, that came in defence of the former troubles: if it be ≈øo, you and I do differ in iudgements, for I do thinke that vigour and fortitude to bee ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary and commendable, which is required to ≈øtand in confractione, as the ≈øcripture tearmeth it, again≈øt vnquiet ≈øtriuing ≈øpirits, as without it, no good in any gouernment can be expected; and albeit in ≈øome it cau≈øe alienations of affections, as you ≈øignifie, yet in others it worketh the contrarie; and that which mo≈øt importeth, it vpholdeth truth, vertue, and Gods cau≈øe. And I would aske you now againe (as ≈øometimes here in pre≈øence I did) in what ca≈øe do you thinke our common cau≈øe of England had beene at this daie if no man had re≈øi≈øted the de≈øignements of the trouble≈øome in this place, or if your endeauours after them had taken place?

¬∂ Let vs example but one example; you talked before your re≈øtraint heere, with the Commi≈ø≈øary of the Inqui≈øition, and you gaue him ≈øuch a relation of Engli≈øh matters, as afterward when M. Doctor Haddock,
and M. Martin Array had talked with him al≈øo, and informed him as they thought of the very truth of matters, he told an honourable man of Rome, and a great friende of mine, that foure Engli≈øh Prie≈øtes hauing talked with him, they had taken from him all li≈øt to beleeue any Engli≈øhmen, or matters more, they told him ≈øo different tales, and yet all of them would ≈øeeme to be men of zeale: well then, if you had bin let alone by his holine≈ø≈øe to deale with all the Cardinalls, and great men of Rome in like ≈øort, would you not haue brought our common cau≈øe in a pretie plight trowe you, and your ≈øelues al≈øo?

¬∂ Moreouer, it appeareth by your papers and depo≈øitions yet extant, that you tooke the way fir≈øt to di≈øcredit ≈øo much as in you lay, M. Blackwell, the fir≈øt, man of all your order that euer was yet in authoritie, and of tho≈øe parts and merittes that all Engli≈øh men know; yea in the very matter of his faith, for that an heriticall propo≈øition was laid to his charge. Secondly were to be di≈øcredited ≈øuch Engli≈øh Prie≈øts as ≈øtood with him, who are the principall of your coat; and with them, all Ie≈øuites, but chieflie tho≈øe that are known to haue laboured mo≈øt in the common cau≈øe, and by who≈øe interce≈ø≈øion Catholique Princes haue bene mo≈øt mooued to a≈ø≈øi≈øt hetherto the ≈øame: and what would haue followed of this? Further, the Protector him≈øelfe mu≈øt haue bin changed, if all de≈øignments in your papers had taken place; the Seminaries mu≈øt haue beene taken from the gouernment of Ie≈øuites, & the whole ≈øocietie called out of England:
and albeit you propo≈øed not in words al the≈øe points together when you came, & how matters ≈øtood: yet were they mentioned as is to bee ≈øeene in your papers from your partners in England; and you ≈øee that now they begin to be giuen abroad againe, in places where you or M. Ch. are or haue beene, and vttered di≈øcontentment.

¬∂ And if all the≈øe points had bene brought to pa≈ø≈øe by you, or at lea≈øt that other point wherevpon you ≈øtood ≈øo much heere, to haue two Arch-prie≈øts in England, not ≈øubordinate the one to the other, but each one ab≈øolute with his traine of ≈øubiects vnder him, oppo≈øite the one again≈øt the other, would not all our cau≈øe haue comen quicklie to ruine? and ≈øhall tho≈øe then that haue ≈øtood again≈øt the≈øe ruines, be accounted ≈øterne and rigorous, or rather coÃÑ ≈øtant & pious, yea friendly towards your ≈øelues? for that with the ruine of the common cau≈øe, yours al≈øo and all other Prie≈øts ≈øhould be inuolued; and now God be thanked, by the good order which his holine≈ø≈øe hath ≈øetled, all is well ended and remedied, if men can be contented; and now Prie≈øts haue their head and ≈øubordination, and Ie≈øuites al≈øo theirs, and both are happilie vnited together, and all ≈øtrife is ended in England, to Gods great glorie and our common good I hope; and his holy name be euer ble≈ø≈øed for the ≈øame.

¬∂ And as for the gouernment of this Colledge here in Rome, whether it be Spani≈øh or Italian, I know not; but ≈øure I am, it tendeth all to vnion, peace, loue, vertue, and learning; & that do the ≈øchollers finde by
the effects, hauing receiued more coÃÑfort, quiet, true mirth, and gaine of learning, in one moneh ≈øithence the reformation, then in ≈øome yeares before; & as for youthes to come vnto it, let no man haue care: for would to God we had ≈øo much maintenance, as we could haue choi≈øe of ≈øchollers to enioy it; and no wi≈øe Catholique is there in England or el≈øe-where, that hearing of this chaunge and reformation, wil refu≈øe to ≈øend his children hither (if he loue them, and may be in hope to haue them placed) for the words or writings of any ≈øuch to the contrarie, as M. Ch. threatneth, who ≈øhal bemonethe lack of liberty. And if M. Ch. or anie other ≈øhould atteÃÑpt to put any thing in print of matters pa≈ø≈øed heere (as our friend writeth is threatned, but I cannot beleeue that any ≈øuch intent can be) the matter would ea≈øily be an≈øwered, for that here remaine authenticall regi≈øters, of all that pa≈ø≈øed by publique authoritie.

¬∂ Well good Sir, I will end then, and pray you to be a mean (as I know your nature to be more moderate, and you prom≈øed it here al≈øo) that things may re≈øt as they were, and are well ended, without renewing of further griefes, as both in wi≈øedome and con≈øcience, and vnder your oathes al≈øo, and vpon paine of cen≈øures both of you are bound: and ≈øurely if the≈øe things ≈øhould be true, which before I haue alleadged to be written hither by credible relators, who≈øe Letters are here extant, I cannot ≈øee how either of you that ≈øhould bee cau≈øe of ≈øo fal≈øe and di≈ø≈øentious reports, can be ≈øafe in con≈øcience for very great ≈øinne, and grieuous cen≈øures al≈øo; but I hope they will not proue true.

¬∂ And as for the reque≈øt you make in your Letter to mee, to deliuer you from the fal≈øe report written hence to Flaunders, and thence to your partes againe, that you ≈øhould confe≈ø≈øe heere to haue beene moued onlie by ambition, to take your la≈øt action in hand, I will deliuer you mo≈øt willingly from anie thing that I haue written, or willed others to write; for as you ≈øaie, I did euer attribute your attempt, rather to errour and lack of con≈øideration, then to ambition; wherein you may ≈øee I was not rigorous; but yet ≈øeeing your matter pa≈ø≈øed by diuers mens hands and knowledge, I cannot let them to thinke, ≈øpeake, or write, what they iudge be≈øt; yet do I ≈øuppo≈øe verilie, that none would ≈øaie or write that you confe≈ø≈øed ≈øo much here, tho I haue heard diuers ≈øpeake and ≈øu≈øpect ≈øo much, vpon the ≈øight of your papers; for that ≈øeeing in diuers papers and ≈øcrolles of your fellowes, which you brought open with you, you were propo≈øed for Bi≈øhops, and in a long di≈øcour≈øe of a friend of yours ≈øent out of Englande after your departure, you two by name were appointed to bee Arch-bi≈øhops & Primates; and that be≈øides this, a principall man of your ≈øide, writing to you certain notes about your me≈ø≈øage, v≈øeth the phra≈øe of your LL. with his owne hand yet here to be ≈øeene; it was much to be ≈øu≈øpected what motion moued you.

¬∂ But (as I ≈øaid) now all is ended, and this and all the re≈øt will ea≈øilie die and be forgotten, (as alreadie I tru≈øt all is forgotten on all hands) if you and M. Ch. do beare your ≈øelues well and prudentlie, and do ≈øtaie and not ≈øtirre vp ≈øuch as do ≈øeeme to fauour or
bemone your cau≈øe, which though you terme by the phra≈øe, of all ≈øorts of people, in your Letter, yet mu≈øt you not deceiue your ≈øelues, for that finallie all tho≈øe ≈øorts mu≈øt be reduced to a verie ≈ømall number, in re≈øpect of others that do condemne your action.

¬∂ Heere in Rome you prooued how the graue≈øt ≈øort of people, both ≈øtraungers and others, iudged of your cau≈øe, after they had heard and examined the ≈øame; I ≈øhewed you al≈øo the Letters and ≈øub≈øcriptions of manie of the chiefe≈øt and mo≈øt principall of our Nation, in Flaunders and England; and ≈øince that time I haue receiued manie more, and manie complaining of the ouermuch lenitie v≈øed in ending of the cau≈øe; how then do all ≈øorts of men crie out of the rigour or iniu≈øtice v≈øed towards you? but in truth it is a verie vncertaine thing to depend vpon the ≈øpeeches of men; diuers ≈øpeake faire, and will bemone a man to his face, when their harts are farre otherwi≈øe; and ≈øome being di≈øcontent or in pa≈ø≈øion them≈øelues vpon other groundes, are glad to take ≈øuch occa≈øions as this of yours is, to disburthen their ≈øtomackes of their owne griefes; others euill enformed at the beginning vpon pittie doo bemone you; which afterwards vpon knowledge of the truth wil change their mindes, and crie crucifige.

¬∂ The onelie way is, to depend of God, and of a good con≈øcience, and to wi≈øh well to all, and ≈øpeake euill of fewe, and to doo the good a man may for all ≈øorts, without re≈øpect what they will ≈øaie or do again; and finally, to haue patience with what≈øoeuer falleth out; and this rule I do coun≈øel to you, and do meane
by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to follow it my ≈øelfe, wi≈øhing no wor≈øe to you and yours then to my owne ≈øoule, as he is witne≈ø≈øe who is mai≈øter of vs both: to who≈øe holie protection I do mo≈øt affectually commend you: and my ≈øelfe to your holie praiers and ≈øacrifices. From Rome, this 9. of October. 1599.

closer.signed: Yours euer mo≈øt readie to ≈øerue you: Robert Par≈øons.

postscript.p: This Letter of F. Par≈øons, did the Arch-prie≈øt ≈øend abroad by his Agent, with an Iniunction to tho≈øe to whom it was carried, that they mu≈øt beleeue all that was contained therin, a≈ø≈øuring them that it was mo≈øt true, notwith≈øtanding hee had made a ≈øeuere Edict not long before again≈øt all ≈øuch as ≈øhould diuuldge anie thing ≈øet out for the ≈øpace of two yeares before, wherein the credit of anie Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon of the Engli≈øh Nation, ≈øhould particularly & by name be touched. How many faultes were in this action of the Arch-prie≈øt, it is not for me to di≈øcypher: but it is verie manife≈øt, that in this Letter of F. Par≈øons, the credit of two Engli≈øh Prie≈øts by name, are very much wounded, and as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme by the cen≈øure following, the Letter de≈øerueth litle commendation for truth therein contained.

div.head: A cen≈øure vpon the Letter which F. Par≈øons writ the 9. of October. 1599. to M. D. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. two bani≈øhed & confined Priests, the one in France, the other in Lorraine, by the ≈øuggestions of F. Par≈øons, for pre≈øuming to goe to Rome, in the affaires of the Church. Giuen by M. I. B.
div.p:
IN the fir≈øt Paragraffe, F. Par≈øons followeth a ≈øu≈øpi≈øition conceiued again≈øt M. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. becau≈øe they did not write vnto him, and yet confe≈ø≈øeth in the ≈øecond Paragraffe, that the ≈øame weeke he had receiued a ≈øtale Letter from M. Bi≈øh. ≈øo that hee might haue left out of the fir≈øt Paragraffe this manife≈øt vngrounded ≈øu≈øpition, and al≈øo this ab≈øurd vntruth, ≈øoone after controlled euen by him≈øelf, that no letter appeared as yet from M. Bi≈øh. And M. Ch. beeing confined to a place, where neither any ordinary Po≈øte was for Rome, or v≈øually pa≈ø≈øed (as F. Par≈øons well knew) he might with more credit haue pretended ≈øome other cau≈øe of ≈øo vniu≈øt a ≈øu≈øpition, as that the two Prie≈øts had for≈øakeÃÑ their good minds, fallen into knowne and acknowledged errours, and broken promi≈øes made at their departure. If Letters might mi≈øcarry in ≈øo loÃÑg a way as was between Rome
and them, what ground was, the not receiuing of Letters from them of tho≈øe conceits? If they will ≈øay that they mu≈øt needs receiue all Letters which come to Rome directed to them, & ≈øo ≈øoone as they do come to them, daily practi≈øe will conuince the contrarie, how≈øoeuer he ≈øhuffleth off this contradiction, that as yet no Letter appeared from M. Bi≈øh. (as F. Par≈øons affirmeth in the fir≈øt Paragraffe) and that he had that weeke receiued a ≈øtale Letter from him (as hee confe≈ø≈øeth in the ≈øecond Paragraffe) but it appeareth both in this former part of F. Par≈øons Letter, and al≈øo in all which followeth in the ≈øame, that F. Par≈øons thought it a great ≈øinne for him≈øelfe, not to de≈øerue blame. What errours were acknowledged at Rome, I know not, but it is very likely that they would haue bene ≈øpecified vpon ≈øo good an occa≈øion as was offered to F. Par≈øons by M. Bi≈øh. and is by F. Par≈øons touched in the 21. Paragraffe: and if they ≈øhould haue acknowledged them≈øelues to haue erred in want of con≈øideration, doubtle≈ø≈øe I ≈øhould (as now it falleth out) beleeue as much, becau≈øe they did willingly ouer≈ølip an opportunitie of hauing a fit meane (maugre their aduer≈øaries) to haue bene heard before they ≈øhould haue bin coÃÑmitted to pri≈øon: which infamy as F. Par≈øons confe≈ø≈øeth, they were in the 10. Paragraffe.

In the ≈øecond Paragraffe, F. Par≈øons boldly without blu≈øhing ≈øaith, that hee receiued a ≈øtale Letter froÃÑ M. Bi≈øh: from whom in the fir≈øt Paragraffe he ≈øaith, as yet no Letter appeared, and both by that Letter, which was receiued, and by that none at all as yet appeared, it is gathered that M. Bi≈øh. was fallen
againe into a pit, out of which as yet he neuer came, ≈øince his fir≈øt fall into it. Tho≈øe commendations of him≈øelfe, which F. Par≈øons tooke no great di≈øgu≈øt to repeate, (meaning that the≈øe Letters ≈øhould pa≈ø≈øe farre and neare, as appeareth in the 6. Paragraffe) were v≈øed by M. Bi≈øh. perchance to trie if by fitting ≈øo well F. Par≈øons humour, he might draw him to that which as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme by M. Bi≈øhops reply, was not in him. What M. Doctor Cic. did write of others complaints I know not; but ≈øo farre as without offence I may, I thinke that it was a mo≈øt lamentable ca≈øe, that two Prie≈øts comming as it became Prie≈øts, towards Rome, to deale with his holine≈ø≈øe about ≈øuch things as belonged to the Church, and were ≈øaid to be done by his order, not confirmed by any Letters froÃÑ the See Apo≈øtolique, or any other ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould be iudged to be laide in pri≈øon with infamy (as is before ≈øhewed out of F. Par≈øons Letters) after many yeares ≈øpent by the ≈øame two Prie≈øts in their Countrey, many daungers of lo≈ø≈øe of libertie, and life ouerpa≈ø≈øed in defence of the Catholique Church, and particularly of the dignitie of the See Apo≈øtolique, and a glorious confe≈ø≈øion of the one in pri≈øon, and bani≈øhment of the ≈øame.

In the 20. Paragraffe I cannot ≈øay what ≈øinne the two prie≈øts did coÃÑmit in relating how they were v≈øed at Rome, for by this Letter of F. Par≈øons it is euident, that great ≈øin may be committed in relating a matter; but if it be true, which is ≈øaid in the ≈øame Paragraffe, that al things were well ended, I do not ≈øee how they could be accu≈øed either of breach of oath, or incurring the cen≈øures, hauing once procured that peace,

Paragraffe it is againe repeated, that all was endeÃÑd, and con≈øequently the two Prie≈øts were di≈øcharged of their bonds, and might very well haue bene ≈øent home againe, had not there bene an intention in ≈øome, that the peace ≈øhould not long endure, which the≈øe two had procured.

In the 21. Paragraffe, F. Par≈øons ≈øheweth him≈øelfe mo≈øt willing to deliuer the two Prie≈øtes from any thing which he had written again≈øt them, or willed others to write. But although F. Par≈øons did euer as he ≈øaith, attribute this their attempt, rather to errour, and lacke of con≈øideration, then to ambition, yet lea≈øt that birds of one feather ≈øhould flie too farre a≈øunder, hee giueth heere ≈øome rea≈øons, why men might thinke that ambition did make the two Prie≈øts to take this action in hand, to giue meÃÑ to vnder≈øtand of his ready mind to hold vp his fellow F. Bald. in this vntruth, of which although M. Bi≈øh. in his an≈øwere to this Letter of F. Par≈øons doth ≈øufficiently di≈øcour≈øe, yet it will not be ami≈ø≈øe to ≈øay ≈øomewhat here concerning F. Par≈øons proofes. For the fir≈øt proofe I haue ≈øpoken with ≈øuch as gathered the petitions, which the Prie≈øts did make, and they doo a≈ø≈øure me, that M. C. was not propo≈øed by any to be made a Bi≈øhop. M. B. was, but if M. C. did carrie tho≈øe writings and kept tho≈øe ≈øecret from M. B. wherein he was named, what proofe is this again≈øt M. B.? To the ≈øecond proofe, I may an≈øwere as once I heard an an≈øwere made for F. Par≈øons, when it was reported heere in England, that all the boyes at S. Omers had con≈øpired to make him a Cardinall, and had written ≈øuch effectuall Letters to the Pope

Par≈øons could not helpe; for who can hinder Letters to be written by ≈øuch as are many hundred miles di≈øtant from them? But I maruell who ≈øhould write this Letter, or whether F. Par≈øons did euer ≈øhewe it to the≈øe 2. Prie≈øts, ≈øo as they might ≈øee it & read it? To the third proofe, M. B. ≈øaith, he could neuer obtain ≈øo much fauour of F. Par≈øons, as to ≈øee tho≈øe notes, and as I am enformed, M. Ch. ≈øaith the ≈øame, although he were mo≈øt importunate with them (e≈øpecially vpon their ofteÃÑ promi≈øes) eueÃÑ vntil the la≈øt houre of his re≈øtraint or aboad at Rome, yea & chaleÃÑged it, that it was forged. I haue heard this coÃÑiecture made, how it was forged. M. C. being at the fir≈øt to goe alone to Rome about the affaires of England, had certaine in≈øtructions ≈øent vnto him froÃÑ D. Ba. who alwaies v≈øed to call M. C. by a name of which the fir≈øt letter was L. by which hee was called when they ≈øtudied together at Rome, and accordingly ≈øent certaine in≈øtructions to . L. which M. C. (≈øometime called M. L.) carried with him to Rome, when hee went in company with M. B. Now what little need of wit there was where there wanted hone≈øtie, I referre me to them who could to the one L. ioyne an other L. and either blot or ≈øcrape away as much as needed of the fir≈øt ≈øtroake of the . in . and ≈øo leaue it L L. which perchance in that writing of M. D. Ba. they might doo with ≈øome facilitie, becau≈øe as all men know, who

Par≈øons, that he told it often, and by often telling it, thought at la≈øt him≈øelfe that it was true; and was not a≈øhamed to write it, and ≈øend it round about the Chri≈øtian world again≈øt the two Prie≈øts; to whom notwith≈øtanding his often promi≈øe vpon their con≈øtant deniall thereof, hee was a≈øhamed to ≈øhewe it when they earne≈øtly demaunded to ≈øee it; might not F. If all this had bene ended in all others, and bene forgotten by them, yet could it not po≈ø≈øibly be forgotten by the two Prie≈øts, who euen to this day ≈øuffer per≈øecution for it, and with ≈øuch extremitie, as the one being driuen by nece≈ø≈øitie to returne into his Countrey for nece≈ø≈øarie reliefe to ≈øu≈øtaine life (notwith≈øtanding he gaue notice of the cau≈øe of his returne to the Arch-prie≈øt, and how for more ≈øafetie he had made an appeale from the ≈øentence, which not hauing inflicted any cen≈øure, nor being to inflict any but vpon ≈øuch, and ≈øuch condition was in the generall opinion of the learned ≈øo ≈øu≈øpended by an appeale made before the euent of the condition, as after the euent of the ≈øame condition, it could take no force again≈øt the appellant) he was vpon this notice giuen to the Arch-prie≈øt pre≈øently denounced (although vntruly) to be ≈øu≈øpended, and without any other cau≈øe giuen, the Arch-prie≈øt at the ≈øame time abrogated, anullated, and tooke away all his faculties, when, or by whom≈øoeuer they were graunted, which doubtle≈ø≈øe, was beyond his Commi≈ø≈øion, which was, to direct, admoni≈øh, and puni≈øh as occa≈øion of offence in breach of his peace ≈øhould be offered, not whom, and when, and for what he li≈øted; much le≈ø≈øe for an entrance into the Countrey, which if it had bene without leaue, or not iu≈øtifiable otherwi≈øe, it did belong to others, and not to him to puni≈øh, & much le≈ø≈øe if it were true, which F. Par≈øons ≈øaith in this 21. Paragraffe, that now all was ended, and that hee tru≈øted all was forgotten on all hands. But to returne to our 22. Paragraffe, what was that
which was ended? If the cau≈øe betweene the Archprie≈øt and all the Prie≈øts were ended, how were the two Prie≈øts ≈øtill kept in bani≈øhment? but wee mu≈øt heere learne a new trick, how to haue all things ended and forgotten. So may the Potent oppre≈ø≈øe whom they may by might, or fraud, and all is well, yea and all is forgotten, if tho≈øe who are oppre≈ø≈øed beare them≈øelues well, and prudently, and do ≈øtay, and not ≈øtirre vp ≈øuch as do ≈øeeme to fauour or bemone their ca≈øe. But perchance the≈øe reports which came to F. Par≈øons eares from Flaunders, and Fraunce, may be ≈øaid to haue bene the hinderance that all was not well on the two Prie≈øts ≈øides (for as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme in the ≈øixt Paragraffe, they were not come to the eares of them, whom they are ≈øaid mo≈øt to concerne) but then before the≈øe reports came to the eares either of the one, or of the other, how was all well, and all forgotten, and yet the two Prie≈øts kept ≈øtill in bani≈øhment? there are Leters vnder Fa. Par≈øons hand to be ≈øeene, to te≈øtifie that all was well, and vnder F. Warfords hand likewi≈øe, and others doubtle≈ø≈øe enough to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, before the≈øe things were obiected again≈øt them, or this deui≈øe wrought for the farther per≈øecuting the two Prie≈øts, and delaying them ≈øtill in bani≈øhment, and confinement, without any proui≈øion made for them to liue, why were they not then di≈ømi≈ø≈øed? Perchance F. Par≈øons did at that time diuine, that the two Prie≈øts might giue ≈øome cau≈øe, that notwith≈øtanding all was well ended, and as he tru≈øted on all hands forgotten, yet
their particular cau≈øe might be exempted from that all, and not onely not be forgotten, but pro≈øecuted ≈øtill vnto the vttermo≈øt that the ≈øtraunge≈øt moode could deui≈øe. Vpon this therefore his diuination, and great fore≈øight, notwith≈øtanding that peremptorily, or po≈øitiuely hee ≈øaid in the 18. Paragraffe, that all was well ended, and iterateth the ≈øame in this 22. Paragraffe, and tru≈øteth that alreadie all is forgotten on all hands, yet he ≈øauceth it with a condition, that is, if M. B. and M. C. do beare them≈øelues well, and prudently, and do ≈øtay, and not ≈øtirre vp ≈øuch as do ≈øeeme to fauour, or bemone their ca≈øe. Now all good Catholiques in England do hartily grieue at the pre≈øent ≈øtirres in England. M. B. and M. Ch. were farre inough off; who hath begunne them? All tho≈øe who did ≈øeeme to fauour, or bemoane the ca≈øe of M. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. had made an attonement with their aduer≈øaries, and forgiuen all tho≈øe ≈ølaunders, and detractious proceedings which were practi≈øed again≈øt them: and neither of them≈øelues, or ≈øtirred vp by M. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. haue they reuiued all that which F. Par≈øons heere confe≈ø≈øeth to haue bene dead, forgotten, or ended. Did not rather F. Rob. Ion. a Ie≈øuite (no great fauourer or bemoaner of M. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. their ca≈øe) broach this diui≈øion again, and renew the ≈øoare (which was, if not cleane healed, yet forgotten, and the offendors forgiuen) by publi≈øhing that the Prie≈øts (who did forbeare to admit M. Black. for their ≈øuperiour, vntill they ≈øawe the Breue in his confirmation) were Schi≈ømatikes, and that all tho≈øe, who ≈øhould not hold the ≈øame, were vnder the cen≈øures
of the Church? Did not M. Black. ≈øoone after, both approue the ≈øame paradox of F. Ion. the Ie≈øuite, and furthermore publi≈øh a re≈øolutioÃÑ ≈øent (as he ≈øaid) from Rome, eyther by Father Wa≈øord or F. Titch. (both Ie≈øuites) which avowed the ≈øame, with many Edicts, and prohibitions, vnder paine of incurring the cen≈øures, that the Prie≈øts ≈øhould not defend them ≈øelues from this mo≈øt ab≈øurd, & iniurious calumniatioÃÑ? Was it ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary that there ≈øhould be tumults in England (which mu≈øt be ≈øaid ≈øtill, no doubt, to be betweene the ≈øecular Prie≈øts, and the Catholiques) that the Ie≈øuites mu≈øt ≈øtil giue the on≈øet, although for to auoyd blame in the opinion of ≈øuch as will blinde them≈øelues, their enterpri≈øes haue bene ≈øo pro≈øecuted by couert Ie≈øuites (who were not knowne but as ≈øecular Prie≈øts) & by the Arch-prie≈øt, as they are generally taken for quarrels among the ≈øecular Prie≈øts? Can F. Par≈øons ≈øay, and not thinke to be laughed at, that the≈øe ≈øtirres are reviued by default of M. Bi≈øh. and M. Ch. their not prudent bearing them≈øelues, or that the Ie≈øuites, and the Arch-prie≈øt were ≈øtirred vp by them, as men who would ≈øeeme to fauour, or bemone their cau≈øe? But had peace long continued in England, which was feared that it would, (had it bin in their power who were ≈øo maruellou≈øly iniured) ≈øome iudged that they ≈øhould mi≈ø≈øe ≈øomewhat at which they aimed, and therefore they ≈øet all things wor≈øe then they were before. We hope we ≈øhal now ≈øhortly at the lea≈øt ≈øee to what end they did it.

Concerning the 23. paragraffe, I cannot ≈øay what either ≈øtraungers, or others, did iudge of the two
Prie≈øts cau≈øe, they them≈øelues mu≈øt an≈øwere how they found ≈øuch as with whom they talked; yet if it be true, which F. Par≈øons relateth in the 16. Paragraffe, it is very likely, that they tolde ≈øome tale, which caried ≈øome weight with it, or el≈øe both the Commi≈ø≈øarie of the Inqui≈øition had litle rea≈øon to v≈øe ≈øuch words as F. Par≈øons there ≈øaith he did, and F. Par≈øons le≈ø≈øe cau≈øe to feare lea≈øt their dealing with all the Cardinalls, and great men in Rome, would (to v≈øe his owne tearme) bring the common cau≈øe in a pretie plight. He vaunteth here, but fal≈øely and iniuriou≈øly again≈øt the principall of our Nation, eyther in Flaunders or England, who ≈øhould complaine of the ouermuch lenitie v≈øed in ending of the cau≈øe, & that none but vpoÃÑ pa≈ø≈øion or mi≈øinformation did bemone theÃÑ. The iudgement of the two Cardinals Caietan, & Burghe≈øe, I ≈øaw in their letters of the 21. of April, 1599. to the Rector or vicerector of the engli≈øh Colledge, and that was, that it was not expedient that the two Prie≈øtes ≈øhould by and by returne vnto tho≈øe parts, where they had maintained controuer≈øies with other of their order. Wherefore they commaunded the two Prie≈øts, that for a time they ≈øhould not pre≈øume to goe without licen≈øe, into the Kingdomes of England, Scotland, and Ireland. I haue bene credibly enformed that neither of them were euer in Scotland or Ireland, and therefore could not maintaine any controuer≈øies there in par≈øonall pre≈øence, but if they did maintaine any, it was by Letters, which they might doo (notwith≈øtanding this proui≈øo) from other parts al≈øo, neither can I learne
that euer they mainteined any ≈øuch in England, but if they had, in my ≈øimple iudgement, it was no good rea≈øon why therefore they ≈øhould be debarred Scotland and Ireland; and although this were the iudgement which was ≈øpecified by the afore≈øaid Letters, yet there was an other iudgement al≈øo, that they ≈øhould not be both in one RegioÃÑ, as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme; for although in the Cardinall Burghe≈øe his Letters of the 15. of September, 1600. to M. C. it is in≈øinuated, that they might choo≈øe their place of bani≈øhment and confinement, (which is a confe≈ø≈øion) that becau≈øe they had controuer≈øies in ≈øome one place, not certainely ≈øet downe where, (if wee looke into the afore≈øaid mentioned Letters of the 21. of Aprill, 1599.) or becau≈øe by their returne into England, ≈øome controuer≈øies might haue growne there (as appeareth by Cardinall Burghe≈øe his Letters of the 15. of September, 1600.) they mu≈øt be bani≈øhed out of all places in the world but one, where they mu≈øt liue in relegation God knoweth how long (for neither is there any certaine time ≈øet downe for this) yet in the an≈øwere vnto it, written by M. C. the 4. of Noumber following, I read that he was not ≈øuffered to be in Fraunce, as he had made his choi≈øe; and if this was not cau≈øe ≈øufficient for hone≈øt men truly enformed of the ending of their cau≈øe to bemoane them ≈øincerely, and from the heart, yet with this circum≈øtance at the lea≈øt it might be, that no proui≈øion being made for them to ≈øu≈øtaine life, they were bani≈øhed out of all ≈øuch places, where they might haue meanes to liue, vpon a ≈øuppo≈øed cau≈øe neuer proued again≈øt
them, or a bare ≈øu≈øpition of what might heereafter bee, vnle≈ø≈øe to goe to Rome to preuent great controuer≈øies, be ≈øaid to be to maintaine cotrouer≈øies, or to giue a ≈øu≈øpition that they would make controuer≈øies, when as that thing by which probably they might a≈ø≈øure them≈øelues that controuer≈øies would growe, came from Rome, and was no where to be remedied but at Rome. And it will appeare by tho≈øe authenticall Regi≈øters in Rome, (if any be kept) that they ≈øought with all ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to his holine≈ø≈øe, to knowe his will in a cau≈øe not made knowne by any Letters before from him, or by any ≈øufficient te≈øtimony otherwi≈øe that it was his order.

In the 24. Paragraffe, F. Par≈øons would ≈øeeme to giue good coun≈øell, although in all that goeth before he ≈øheweth how litle he careth to follow any, but rather aduentureth to ≈øay or doo, what commeth into his minde, and ≈øeeketh afterward to per≈øwade ≈øuch as again≈øt whom he worketh to haue patience, and ≈øay nothing but be peaceable, not to finde fault, or blame any his proceedings, lea≈øt that tumults ari≈øe thereon, as who did re≈øolue rather to goe through with what≈øoeuer he attempteth, then to recall, or reclaime him≈øelf at any time, when he hath done ami≈ø≈øe; for proofe whereof, he cau≈øed this Letter (as it appeareth in the 6. Paragraffe) to be coÃÑmunicated to others, be≈øide tho≈øe to whom it was writteÃÑ, who ≈øhuld al≈øo publi≈øh it further without any ≈øhame (as it is to be feared) of the follies, or con≈øcience for the vntruthes conteined therein, and with as much breuitie as the matter would ≈øuffer declared in this Cen≈øure.

div.p:

I ≈øhould now according to the order I propo≈øed, examine and confute, ≈øundrie fal≈øe calumniations, which you let fall by the way; as that we depo≈øed we had nothing el≈øe to ≈øay, and that wee could not name a dozen Prie≈øts for vs, and as your followers amplifying, ≈øuch flying tales reported, wee had not halfe a dozen that gaue vs their ≈øuffrages, when we had twentie nine in writing with vs, ≈øome of them ≈øpeaking al≈øo for others, and yet neither ≈øought for many, nor ≈øtaide about that matter, but contenting our ≈øelues with ≈øome of the mo≈øt aunciente≈øt, mo≈øt learned and of be≈øt reputation in our Countrey: tru≈øted to the waight of rea≈øon, which we had on our ≈øide, and to the equitie of the magi≈øtrates, before whom we went to pre≈øent our ≈øelues. Againe, how ridiculous was it to expect of them that are to be ≈øo narrowly ≈øearched when they pa≈ø≈øe out of the Countrey, that they bring their te≈øtimonies with them in great ≈øheetes of paper, as though the vertue of witne≈ø≈øes lay in the bigne≈ø≈øe of the paper, and that we ≈øhould haue brought ≈øome Princes
Letters patents with a broad Seale at them; whereas the magi≈øtrates are our enemies. The≈øe and many ≈øuch like I will leape ouer, that I may at length come to an end; and if my Letter ≈øeeme long, let the blame be imputed vnto yours, which, in an≈øwere to halfe a dozen lines, grew into two ≈øheetes of paper and a halfe: if it be thought too ≈øharp, let it be well waighed, whether men fir≈øt hardly v≈øed in fact, and afterwards by wordes and Letters much damnified in their credits, haue not iu≈øt cau≈øe to write roundly: and if you like not to be ≈øo freely reprehended, be not ≈øo laui≈øh of your penne, for vnle≈ø≈øe my fore≈øight faile me, you are like hereafter to be no more ≈øpared of many then you ≈øpare others. Wherefore to drawe vnto a conclu≈øion, apply to your ≈øelfe ≈øome part of the good coun≈øell you gaue me in the latter end of yours, haue patience with what≈øoeuer falleth out, and per≈øwade your ≈øelfe that he which offendeth many, is ≈øure to be offended by many: wherefore holding your ≈øelfe within the bounds of your religion, meddle with other mens matters as litle as you may; and if for the common good of our countrey you plea≈øe to be doing, take rather the way of mildene≈ø≈øe which winneth mens hearts, then of rigour which lightly offendeth all. Follow the noble, prudent, and admirable ≈øteps of that rare ornament of our countrey, and ≈øingular light of the Catholique Church, Cardinall Allen, who carried him≈øelfe ≈øo courteou≈øly towards all men, ≈øo charitably and withall ≈øo wi≈øely, that he was able to haue done with vs Prie≈øts what he would mo≈øt ea≈øily; and did hold
the Laie Gentlemen in ≈øuch a reuerend and louing awe, that albeit ≈øome of them were verie prone to contentions & quarels, yet his authoritie and coun≈øaile ≈øo brideled and raigned all exorbitant humors, that in his time, to his perpetuall prai≈øe, no great flames of di≈ø≈øention bur≈øt out, e≈øpecially among≈øt vs Prie≈øts, when you taking the contrary cour≈øe of ≈øeuerity, haue made an open breach among≈øt vs alreadie, and God knoweth what may fall out heereafter, if you looke not vnto it in time, which becau≈øe you are wi≈øe, I hope you wil do, and ≈øo ≈øhall you purcha≈øe vnto your ≈øelfe much more good will and quietne≈ø≈øe in this life, and better a≈ø≈øurance (if I be not farre deceiued) of euerla≈øting repo≈øe, & ioy in the life to come, the which with all my heart I wi≈øh you; and ≈øo humbly commending my ≈øelfe vnto you,

closer.date: I take my leaue the 10. of Aprill. Anno. 1600.

div.head: A LETTER OF Mr. MV. TO Father Par≈øons.
div.p:
WEll, well, Fa. Par≈øons, I pray God ≈øend you a more ≈øincere and quiet ≈øpirit. I finde that true daily more and more, which ofteÃÑ I haue heard good Cardinal Allein, Father Holt, and others of your owne coate, report of you, that you were a man of too violent and hard a nature. It were high time that you ≈øhould permit your ≈øelfe & vs, to carrie our gray haires in peace to our graues. The trouble and ≈øcandall you haue wrought in our Church the≈øe late yeares by your polliticke cour≈øes, doo quite cancell all your former de≈øert. Was our peace and vnion made at the comming of his holines Breue, and the mo≈øt iniurious calumnie of ≈øchi≈øme and enormious di≈øobedience to the See Apo≈øtolicke, rai≈øed and coÃÑtinued mo≈øt pre≈øumptuou≈øly again≈øt vs & our gho≈øtly children by your ≈øocietie here, to the greeuous ≈øcandall of our whole Nation: was it, I ≈øaie, put vp by vs, and for loue of peace and vnion forgiuen; that pre≈øently after we had receiued the authoritie, and ≈øubmitted our ≈øelues to it, you, and yours might more ≈øafely and liberally renew the infamie again≈øt vs, and
by the Arch-prie≈øtes authoritie (a≈ø≈øured to you in what≈øoeuer you li≈øted to attempt again≈øt any) at your plea≈øures per≈øecute and oppre≈ø≈øe vs? You haue in the highe≈øt degree, di≈øhonored & iniured Peters Chaire, whiles by your cunning you ≈øo enormiou≈ølie abu≈øed our bretheren (as good doubtle≈ø≈øe as your ≈øelfe) appealing and comming in all humble & dutiful manner to the Apo≈øtolicke See; defaming them, and auerting his Ho. minde from them, as from vile and badde per≈øons, by your vntrue reports before they came; and procuring (a mo≈øt impious and horrible thing to be recounted for perpetuall, yet hateful memorie, of your fact) them to be impri≈øoned as notorious malefactors, before they had bene heard, ≈øtopping vp all meanes of acce≈ø≈øe to his holines, and your ≈øelfe playing their Iaylour, a fit office doubtle≈ø≈øe for ≈øo well di≈øpo≈øed a religious per≈øon, and finally procuring their hard bani≈øhment, to no le≈ø≈øe di≈øhonour to the See Apo≈øtolicke, (abu≈øed by your information) then to your owne perpetuall ignominie. And whiles you haue done all this by abu≈øe of the ≈øupreame authoritie, through your vncon≈øcionable and vntrue informations: you giue all our Nation here cau≈øe enough, neuer to admire or hereafter to exclaime again≈øt the iniquitie of aduer≈øaries, who may truly iu≈øtifie them≈øelues in their hard proceedings again≈øt vs, by the≈øe vncon≈øcionable cour≈øes of yours. A lamentable ca≈øe, that now by the polliticke ≈øhifts of one per≈øon of religious profe≈ø≈øion, orderly appealing to S. Peters Chaire, mu≈øt be thought a tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, and puni≈øhed as a greeuous crime. Our ≈øtatute
of Premunire may well be repealed now: Father Par≈øons a Ie≈øuite, hath laid a plot ≈øufficient enough to hinder appellation or acce≈ø≈øe to the See of Rome. Is it po≈ø≈øible this iniquitie of yours ≈øhould be kept ≈øecret from the world? Is it po≈ø≈øible his holine≈ø≈øe and the gratious Cardinalls you haue ≈øo notably abu≈øed, ≈øhould neuer be brought to knowe the innocencie of vs whom you haue thus wronged and per≈øecuted in our bretheren, and neuer can cea≈øe to afflict? Will they neuer, thinke you, finde out your deceit, and by iu≈øt di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of our cau≈øe, relieue our mi≈øeries, and repay you your de≈øerts? The clamours of innocent men, will in time no doubt, a≈øcend vp to heauen, and wee cannot but hope that our Lord Ie≈øu (who≈øe worke we haue in hand, and who≈øe glorie wee ≈øeeke with innumerable vexations for his ≈øake) will once ≈øtirre vp and direct his Vicar, to iudge and di≈øcerne our cau≈øe, and to deliuer vs from your mo≈øt violent and wrongfull oppre≈ø≈øions. In the ende it will be found we were no Schi≈ømatickes, nor in the lea≈øt point that may bee deui≈øed by an vncon≈øcionable head, di≈øobedient to his holine≈ø≈øe, or any ≈øuperiour he hath or ≈øhall appoint ouer vs. I am per≈øwaded ≈øurely, that God will haue you and your adherents knowne ere it be long. For defame vs before wee come; impri≈øon vs at our arriuall; keepe vs clo≈øe from being ≈øeene or heard; yet ≈øhall you not goe ≈øo away with your iniquitie; we are re≈øolued verily, that with our good names, you ≈øhal bereue vs al≈øo of our liues, before we ≈øit downe with this vnde≈øerued calumnie. Either will wee bee prooued no Schi≈ømatickes, or
found no liuing men. We haue laboured what wee could, that the controuer≈øie might be taken vp, and haue a quiet end among our ≈øelues before it were carried further. This would not be graunted by you and yours, but for our good endeuours, they take from vs our faculties (I might haue ≈øaid you take) whereby we liue; we wi≈øh rather you had at once taken from vs our liues, but we take it to be Gods prouidence, that enforced to come to buckle with you once againe before S. Peters Chaire, we may cleare our ≈øelues, and di≈øcypher what your ≈øelfe, M. Haddock, and others of you are: for better, or le≈ø≈øe euill it is, you ≈øuffer as you haue de≈øerued, then eyther the See Apo≈øtolicke be abu≈øed and deluded by you, or our afflicted Church be thus exceedingly di≈øturbed by men that are fledde from the worke and campe of Gods ≈øouldiers, and ≈øome of you, of no great edifying conuer≈øation whiles they were among vs. Mo≈øt glad we would be (God is our witne≈ø≈øe) if we might on all ≈øides be at peace and ≈øincere friend≈øhip one with an other: but if you will not permit this, Gods will be done: we mu≈øt defend our good names, and our childrens, as deare vnto vs as our liues; in which the mo≈øt of vs I hope, finde no ≈øuch ≈øweetene≈ø≈øe (how plea≈øantly ≈øoeuer you and yours liue) among the≈øe innumerable aduer≈øities, as we can de≈øire or delight to keepe them, with the infamies you haue mo≈øt vncharitably and vniu≈øtly laid vpon vs. We impute no fault nor blame to his holine≈ø≈øe, or his Cardinalls, in beleeuing your fal≈øe informations again≈øt vs, till wee come to ≈øpeake for our
≈øelues: for who, not knowing your conditions, but he may ea≈øily be enduced to beleeue what you ≈øay? your age and gray hayres, requiring a true tongue, and your religious profe≈ø≈øion requiring al≈øo, a ≈øincere, charitable, and quiet di≈øpo≈øition, and not a turbulent, reuengefull, and craftie carriage in word or deed? Ie≈øu ≈øend vs all his grace, and deliuer me and all good men from your mi≈øchiefe. London 13. of Nouember. 1600.

closer.signed: Yours as you are to our Church, I. M.
